name: Employment Agreement Effective Date
description:
The Employment Agreement Effective Date is the date from which the rights, obligations, and provisions of the Employment Agreement become legally binding and enforceable between the parties. It marks the commencement of the parties’ duties and responsibilities under the agreement. 

Clearly defining the effective date helps avoid confusion about when contractual obligations begin, ensures proper contract lifecycle management, and reduces the risk of disputes regarding timing or enforceability.

metadata.llm_instructions: This date may be the same as the execution date (the date the contract is signed) but can also be set to a different, specified date—either earlier or later—depending on the parties’ intentions or upon fulfilment of certain conditions precedent.

name: Governing Law (Jurisdiction)
description:
1. General Principles
- In employment contracts, the parties cannot freely choose any legal jurisdiction to govern their contract if doing so would violate mandatory laws designed to protect employees.
- Many countries impose rules that the employment relationship is governed by the law of the country where the employee habitually carries out their work or where the employment connection is strongest. This is to ensure minimum employee protections under local labor laws.
- Parties cannot choose a governing law to circumvent mandatory labor protections of the country or state where the employee actually works, regardless of contract stipulation.
- In cross-border contexts, international/private law or local statutes dictate that the chosen law cannot deprive employees of core protections afforded by the law of their actual work location.
- Even if an employment agreement includes a choice of law clause selecting a foreign jurisdiction, courts may refuse to apply that choice if it undermines mandatory statutory protections or public policy of the employee's working location.

2. On-Site Employment
Scenario 1: Both Parties in the Same Country/State
The governing law is the country or state in which both the employer and employee are based and where the work is performed.
Example: If both are based in California and the work is performed there, set employment_governing_law_jurisdiction = "California, USA".

Scenario 2: Employer and Employee in Different Countries/States, Work Performed at Employer’s Location
The governing law is the country or state where the work is physically performed.
Example: If a French employer hires a German national who relocates to work in Paris, set employment_governing_law_jurisdiction = "France".

3. Remote Employment
Scenario 3: Employee Working Remotely in a Different Country/State than the Employer
The governing law is the country or state where the employee habitually works (remote location).
The parties may agree on another law, but local mandatory labor laws of the employee’s work location will override unfavorable contract terms.
Example: UK employer hires a remote employee based in Spain. Set employment_governing_law_jurisdiction = "Spain".

4. Hybrid Employment
Scenario 4: Split Work Between Employer’s Office (Country A) and Home/Remote (Country B)
Assess where the employee "habitually" works the majority of the time. 
If truly split or ambiguous seek legal advice. However the mandatory rules of both jurisdictions may apply.
Example: US employer, employee works three days/week on-site in London and two days/week from home in Paris. If most time is in London, set employment_governing_law_jurisdiction = "UK", but clarify applicability of French labor law for remote work days.

Cross-border Teams: Apply local law for each employee based on their habitual work location, even if managing under one global set of policies.

metadata.llm_instructions:
If jurisdiction known by HR: Incorporate governing law clause specifying jurisdiction name.
Example: “Ontario, Canada”
Activate jurisdiction-specific legal notes and advisory for contract clauses.
End selection process here.

Mandatory Legal Considerations:
Advise client that the governing law chosen must not violate mandatory statutory employee protections in the employee’s work location.

Where the chosen law conflicts with mandatory protections of the employee's location, local mandatory laws generally prevail notwithstanding contract terms.

If jurisdiction unknown by HR: proceed to Step 3

Step 3
Use employment_place_work value to determine governing law:

A. On-Site Work: Governing law is the law of the country/state where the employee physically works.
Example: Employee working in Germany → governing law = “Germany”.

B. Remote Work: Governing law is the law of the country/state where the employee performs remote work.
Example: Employee working remotely from Spain → governing law = “Spain”.

C. Hybrid Work: Request indication of majority work location (on-site or remote).
If majority on-site, governing law = laws of physical workplace jurisdiction.
If majority remote, governing law = laws of remote work jurisdiction.
Example: Employee works 60% on-site in UK, 40% remote in France → governing law = “UK”.

Post-Selection Activation: Once governing law is determined, activate jurisdiction-specific guidance and compliance notes throughout the contract review process to assist client in adapting clauses to local legal requirements.

name: Employer Name
description: This parameter represents the full legal or commonly recognized name of the Employer. It is used to identify the Employer and the value should be precise and consistent with official records or commonly accepted usage to ensure accurate identification and data matching.

name: Employer Company Jurisdiction
description: This parameter specifies the legal jurisdiction under which the employer is registered and operates for the purposes of the employment contract. It determines which country's or region's laws and regulations govern the employment relationship, including contractual rights, obligations, dispute resolution, and statutory benefits.

metadata.llm_instructions:
- Identify the specific country, state, or region where the company is legally incorporated or registered.
- Use standardized jurisdiction names consistent with recognized geopolitical entities (e.g., “Delaware, USA,” “England and Wales,” “Singapore”, "Canada, Ontario").

name: Employer Company Registration Number
description:
This parameter specifies the unique official registration number assigned to an employer by a government authority, tax agency, or social security administration. It serves as an identifier for the employer within employment records, payroll submissions, and government communications.

Purpose and Use
- Identification: Uniquely identifies the employer in employment contracts, tax filings, social security records, and official submissions.
- Compliance: Required for legal compliance related to payroll, tax withholding, social security contributions, employee benefits, and other employment-related filings.
- Verification: Enables government agencies and financial institutions to verify the legitimacy and identity of the employer.

Typical Scenarios
- Included in employment contracts to clearly identify the employing legal entity.
- Used when registering new employees with governmental payroll or tax authorities.
- Required on statutory forms (e.g., tax returns, social security filings).

metadata.llm_instructions:
- The format and name of the registration number may vary by country (e.g., Employer Identification Number in the US, PAYE Reference in the UK, SIRET in France, etc.).
- The number is typically assigned when the employer registers with a tax or regulatory authority before hiring employees.
- It should be kept up to date and referenced in all official employer communications or filings where required.

Example Values:
Country	Registration Number Name	Format Example
United States	Employer Identification Number (EIN)	12-3456789
Ireland	Employer Registration Number	1234567T
United Kingdom	PAYE Reference	123/A45678
India	PAN (for employers)	ABCDE1234F

name: Employer Address
description:
This parameter specifies the official physical or principal place of business address of the Employer. It is used to clearly identify the employer’s location within the employment contract and related documentation. Including the employer’s address is essential for formal communications, legal notices, and compliance with employment regulations.

Purpose and Use
- Identification: Provides a precise location to identify the Employer in the contract and for official purposes.
- Legal Compliance: Many jurisdictions require that employment contracts include the employer’s address or principal place of business.
- Communication: Serves as the official address for delivering notices, correspondence, and other legal communications between Employer and Employee.
- Record Keeping: Employers must maintain and provide this information for government filings, tax purposes, and inspections.

Practical Considerations
- The address should reflect the Employer’s main office, registered office, or principal place of business relevant to the employment relationship.
- If the Employer operates multiple locations, the primary place of business for the Employee’s role may be specified separately.
- The address format should comply with local postal standards and include sufficient details (street, city, postal code, country) for clarity.

name: Employee Name
description:
This parameter specifies the full legal name of the individual employee entering into the employment contract. It is used to clearly and uniquely identify the employee throughout the contract and related employment documentation.

Purpose and Use
- Identification: Ensures the employee is correctly identified in all contractual, legal, and administrative records.
- Contract Validity: Including the employee’s full legal name is essential for the enforceability and clarity of the employment agreement.
- Record Keeping: Facilitates accurate maintenance of payroll, benefits, tax, and personnel records.
- Communication: Used in official notifications, correspondence, and documentation related to the employee’s employment.

Practical Considerations
- The name should match the employee’s official identification documents (e.g., passport, national ID).
- It should include first name(s) and surname(s) as legally recognized.
- Any preferred names or informal forms should be recorded separately if needed for daily use but not substituted for the legal name in the contract.
- Care should be taken to spell the name correctly to avoid legal ambiguity.

name: Employee Address
description:
This parameter specifies the full residential or correspondence address of the employee as part of their identification in the employment contract. It ensures the employee is clearly and uniquely identified and provides a location for official communication and legal notices related to the employment relationship.

Purpose and Use
- Identification: Accurately identifies the employee within the contract and employment records.
- Legal Compliance: Many jurisdictions require the employee’s address to be recorded in the employment contract or written employment particulars.
- Communication: Serves as the official address for delivering employment-related communications, notices, tax documents, and other correspondence.
- Record Keeping: Supports maintenance of accurate personnel files, payroll administration, and compliance with statutory reporting requirements.

Practical Considerations
- The address should reflect the employee’s usual place of residence or mailing address.
- Should be kept up to date; employees often have an obligation to notify the employer of any changes in address.
- Employers must ensure confidentiality and appropriately protect personal address information.

name: Employee Email
description:
This parameter specifies the employee’s official email address used for all employment-related communications. It serves as a primary channel for sending notices, updates, official correspondence, and any digital communication between the Employer and Employee.

Purpose and Use
- Communication: Provides a direct and formal means to communicate employment information, including contract updates, policy changes, and notices.
- Verification: Helps verify the identity of the employee in digital correspondence and HR systems.
- Record Keeping: Ensures that email communication can be accurately logged and referenced as part of the employee’s records.
- Flexibility: Supports remote communication and enhances responsiveness, especially in modern hybrid or remote working arrangements.

Practical Considerations
- The employee’s email should be kept current and monitored regularly.
- The Employer and Employee should agree on using this email as an official communication channel.
- Confidentiality and data protection obligations apply to email communications containing personal or sensitive information.
- Employers may have policies outlining acceptable email use for official correspondence.

name: Employment Start Date
description:
This parameter specifies the official date when the employee’s employment with the company begins. It marks the commencement of all rights, responsibilities, and obligations under the employment agreement. From this date, the employee is formally recognized as part of the organization, and all contractual terms such as salary, benefits, probation period, and other employment conditions take effect.

The value should be a specific calendar date that is agreed upon by both the employer and the employee before the contract is signed. When selecting this date, consider the following:
- The start date should allow enough time for any required onboarding, background checks, or work permit processes to be completed.
- It should align with the operational needs of the company and the availability of the employee.
- If the employee is transitioning from another job, ensure the date allows for any required notice period or relocation.
- The chosen date should not be retroactive and should reflect when the employee is expected to begin performing their duties.

name: Job Title
description:
This parameter determines the official job title assigned to the employee, such as "Software Engineer," "Marketing Manager," or "Sales Associate." The job title should accurately reflect the employee’s main role and responsibilities within the organization. Choosing a clear and appropriate job title helps set expectations for duties, aligns with industry standards, and may influence compensation, career progression, and eligibility for certain benefits or professional development opportunities.

Select a job title that best matches the actual work the employee will perform and is consistent with titles used within your organization and industry. Avoid overly vague or generic titles, as well as titles that may not reflect the employee’s true level of responsibility or expertise.

name: Reporting Manager Inclusion
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a clause specifying the employee's direct reporting line within the organization.

When set to true, the agreement includes a clause stating that the Employee shall report directly to a designated manager. This designation clarifies supervisory relationships, establishes accountability, and defines the primary communication channel for work assignments, performance feedback, and managerial oversight.

This clause also provides the Company with flexibility by allowing it to reassign the Employee’s reporting manager as necessary to accommodate organizational changes or improvements in operational efficiency.

Including this parameter ensures transparency in organizational structure, helping the Employee understand to whom they are accountable and facilitating clear lines of authority and responsibility.

When set to false, the agreement omits this clause, which might be suitable for roles with unconventional reporting arrangements or where such detail is addressed separately.

name: Reporting Manager Name
description:
This parameter specifies the full name of the individual who will act as the employee’s direct supervisor or manager. The reporting manager is responsible for overseeing the employee’s performance, providing guidance, assigning tasks, and serving as the main point of contact for work-related issues.

Choose a manager who is directly involved in the employee’s department or function and has the authority to supervise, evaluate, and support the employee’s work. Ensure the manager’s name is current and accurate to avoid confusion and to establish a clear reporting relationship from the outset.

name: Job Description Attached
description:
This parameter indicates whether a detailed job description document is attached to the employment contract. If set to "true," it means the contract includes an additional document outlining the employee’s specific duties and responsibilities. If set to "false," no such document is attached, and the contract may rely on a general description of duties within the main agreement.

Guidance on Choosing the Value:
- Set this parameter to "true" if you want to provide a comprehensive, written job description as part of the employment agreement. This is recommended for clarity and legal certainty, especially for roles with specific or complex responsibilities.
- Set to "false" if a separate job description is not provided, but be aware this may lead to ambiguity regarding the employee’s role.
- Attaching a job description is considered best practice, as it helps both parties understand and agree on the scope of the position from the outset.

name: Employment Appointment Term Type
description:
This parameter defines the overall duration and termination conditions of the Employee’s appointment. It specifies whether the employment is ongoing without a fixed end date, set for a specific fixed period, or a combination of an initial fixed term followed by an open-ended period with notice requirements.

Possible values:
- indefinite:	Employment continues indefinitely until either party ends it by giving the required notice.
- pure-fixed-term: Employment lasts for a predetermined period and automatically ends on a specified date without the need for notice.
- fixed-term-with-notice:	Employment has a fixed end date but may be ended earlier by either party providing notice as agreed.
-initial-fixed-then-notice:	Employment begins with an initial fixed term and, upon expiry, continues indefinitely until terminated by notice.

Considerations: 
- The chosen appointment term type determines how long the employment lasts and the conditions under which it can be ended.
- Indefinite terms provide ongoing employment with notice requirements for termination.
- Fixed-term contracts provide certainty about the end date but may include options for early termination.
- Hybrid terms combine an initial fixed period with ongoing employment subject to notice.
- Clear communication of these terms helps avoid misunderstandings and legal risks.

name: Pure Fixed Term - Expiry Date
description:
This parameter specifies the exact calendar date on which a fixed-term employment contract will end. It defines the final day of the employee’s appointment under a fixed-term arrangement. After this date, the employment relationship automatically terminates without the need for notice or further action by either party.

Practical Considerations
- The contract will end automatically on the specified date, and neither party is required to provide notice unless otherwise stipulated in the agreement.
- If the employment continues beyond this date without a new agreement, it may be considered an indefinite contract under certain legal frameworks.
- The end date should be communicated clearly to avoid misunderstandings about the employment period.

name: Fixed Term with Notice - Expiry Date
description:
This parameter specifies the final date on which a fixed-term employment contract will expire, subject to earlier termination by either party in accordance with the contract’s termination provisions. It marks the scheduled end of the employment unless ended sooner with proper notice.

Purpose and Use
- Defines the maximum duration of the fixed-term appointment.
- Allows for early termination consistent with agreed notice requirements.
- Provides certainty about the contract’s scheduled conclusion while maintaining flexibility.

Practical Considerations
- The contract will automatically end on this date if not terminated earlier.
- Early termination must comply with the notice and procedural requirements set out in the termination clause.
- Clear documentation of this date helps prevent disputes about contract duration and termination rights.

name: Initial Fixed Term then with Notice - Expiry Date
description:
This parameter specifies the calendar date on which the initial fixed term of the employment appointment expires. It marks the end of the guaranteed fixed period, after which the employment continues on an ongoing basis subject to termination by notice.

Purpose and Use
- Defines the guaranteed minimum duration of employment.
- Provides clarity and certainty for both Employer and Employee regarding the initial term.
- Serves as a transition point from fixed-term to indefinite employment status.

Practical Considerations
- The employment cannot be terminated by notice before this date unless otherwise agreed or for cause.
- After this date, the employment continues indefinitely and may be terminated according to the contract’s termination provisions.
- Clear communication of this date helps prevent misunderstandings about employment duration and termination rights.

name: Probation Period
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employee’s appointment includes a probationary period at the start of employment. A probationary period is a trial phase during which the Employer evaluates the Employee’s performance, conduct, and suitability for the role before confirming ongoing employment.

Possible Values and Explanation:
- true: A probationary period applies. The Employee’s performance will be monitored during this initial period, and the employment may be terminated with shorter notice if necessary. The Employer may also have the option to extend the probation period.
- false: No probationary period applies. The Employee’s appointment begins without a trial phase, and standard termination provisions apply from the start.

Purpose:
Including a probationary period provides flexibility for the Employer to assess new Employees and make early termination decisions with reduced notice requirements if the Employee does not meet expectations. It also sets clear expectations for the Employee regarding their initial evaluation period.

name: Duration of Probation Period
description:
This parameter specifies the length of the probationary period at the start of the Employee’s appointment, expressed in months. The probationary period is a defined trial phase during which the Employer evaluates the Employee’s performance, conduct, and overall suitability for the role.

Purpose and Use:
- Defines the duration of the probationary period during which the Employee’s employment may be subject to different termination terms, typically involving shorter notice periods.
- Provides a clear timeframe for both Employer and Employee to assess whether the employment relationship should continue on a permanent basis.
- Helps manage expectations and legal compliance by specifying how long the probation period lasts.

Typical Values:
- Common probation periods range from 1 to 6 months, depending on the role, industry, and jurisdiction.
- The chosen duration should align with company policy and applicable employment laws.
- The default chosen is 3 months.

Practical Considerations:
- The probation period duration affects notice periods and termination rights during this phase.
- Employers may have the option to extend the probation period beyond the initial term if permitted by the contract.
- Clear communication of the probation period length helps avoid misunderstandings and potential disputes.

name: Probation Termination Notice Period
description:
This parameter specifies the length of notice, in weeks, that either the Employer or the Employee must give to terminate the employment during the probationary period. The notice period during probation is typically shorter than the notice required after the probation period ends.

Purpose and Use:
- Defines the minimum advance warning required to end the employment relationship during the probationary period.
- Provides flexibility for both parties to end the employment quickly if the arrangement is not suitable.
- Ensures compliance with company policy and applicable employment laws regarding minimum notice during probation.

Typical Values:
- The default and most common value is 1 week, but this may vary depending on the role, industry, or local legal requirements.
- Some organizations may use longer or shorter periods based on their needs.

Practical Considerations:
- The notice period should be clearly communicated to the Employee at the start of employment.
- Termination during probation with the specified notice period should be handled in accordance with any applicable legal requirements.
- A shorter notice period during probation allows for greater flexibility and faster decision-making for both parties.

name: Probation Period Extension
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement provides the Employer with the discretion to extend the initial probationary period.

When enabled (true), the Employer may extend the probationary period for an additional length of time if more time is needed to assess the Employee’s performance or suitability for the role.

This extension allows flexibility in cases where the initial probation period was insufficient due to factors such as absences, incomplete performance data, or a need for further evaluation.

The extension period is usually limited to a reasonable duration and the Employee should be notified in writing of the extension and its terms.

Including this parameter ensures clear expectations for both parties and reduces the risk of premature termination or misunderstandings about the probationary evaluation timeline.

When disabled (false), the initial probation period is fixed and no contractual right to extend it is granted to the Employer.

name: Probation Period Extension Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the maximum length of time, in months, by which the Employer may extend the initial probationary period. The extension allows additional time to assess the Employee’s performance and suitability for the role if the Employer deems it necessary.

Purpose and Use:
- Provides flexibility for the Employer to prolong the probationary evaluation period beyond the initial term.
- Ensures that the Employer has sufficient time to make a well-informed decision regarding the Employee’s continued employment.
- Helps manage situations where additional training, support, or performance improvement is required before confirmation.

Typical Values:
- A common default extension period is 3 months, though this may vary depending on company policy or jurisdictional requirements.
- Extensions should be reasonable and compliant with applicable employment laws.

Practical Considerations:
- The extension of the probation period should be communicated clearly and in writing to the Employee before the original probation period expires.
- The terms of the probation extension, including any changes to notice periods or evaluation criteria, should be specified.
- Employers should avoid excessive or repeated extensions to prevent potential legal challenges.

name: Probation Completion Notice
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employer is required to provide the Employee with written confirmation upon successful completion of the probationary period. It ensures that the Employee is formally notified when they have satisfactorily passed the probation.

Possible Values and Explanation:
- true: The Employer will provide the Employee with written notice confirming successful completion of the probationary period.
- false: No formal written confirmation of probation completion is provided, although the Employee’s continued employment implies successful completion.

Purpose:
Providing written confirmation of probation completion helps clarify the Employee’s status, reduces uncertainty, and formalizes the transition from probationary to confirmed employment. It can also serve as a record for both parties.

Practical Considerations:
- Written notice can be an official letter, email, or other documented communication.
- It may include details about the Employee’s performance, any conditions, or next steps.
- If no notice is given, the Employee should understand that continued employment generally indicates successful completion.

name: Incorporation of Previous Employment
description:
This parameter determines whether an employee’s previous period of employment with another employer is recognized as continuous service for the purposes of the current employment agreement.

When this parameter is true, the employee’s service with their previous employer (as identified in the agreement) will be counted as part of their period of continuous employment with the current employer. Recognizing this continuity can affect the calculation of statutory employment rights and benefits, such as redundancy pay, notice periods, and unfair dismissal protection, all of which depend on the overall length of continuous service.

When this parameter is false, only the service with the current employer is recognized as continuous employment, and any employment history with a previous employer is not included for these purposes.

Purpose:
The parameter provides clarity to both employer and employee regarding whether and how previous service is included in continuous employment calculations, which is particularly important in cases of business transfers, mergers, or reorganizations.

name: Previous Employer Name
description: This parameter specifies the name of the employee’s prior employer, whose period of service is recognized as part of the employee’s continuous employment with the current employer. This parameter is used when the employment agreement provides that time spent working for a previous company will count towards the employee’s total period of continuous employment for statutory and contractual purposes (such as redundancy, notice, or benefits calculations).

name: Previous Employment Start Date
description:
parameter records the date on which the employee began their employment with their previous employer. This date is used in the context of recognizing prior service as continuous employment with the current employer—meaning it marks the starting point for calculating the employee’s total period of continuous service when both past and present employment periods are aggregated.

Purpose:
To establish the official beginning of the employee’s recognized continuous service, ensuring accuracy in determining statutory entitlements, such as redundancy pay, notice periods, or other benefits linked to length of service.

name: Place of Work Arrangement
description:
This parameter specifies the employee’s principal work arrangement under the contract. It sets expectations regarding where the employee is to carry out their duties, as follows:

Onsite: The employee's normal place of work is a specific location designated by the employer, such as the company’s office, plant, or other business premises. The employer may require the employee to work at other locations within a reasonable distance as business needs dictate. This arrangement emphasizes a physical, employer-controlled work environment.

Remote: The employee is permitted to perform their duties from a location of their own choosing outside the employer’s premises, subject to prior approval by the employer and adherence to company policies. The employee must maintain a suitable and safe work environment and is expected to perform their duties to the same standard as if working on-site. The employer may require occasional attendance at company premises or other locations, particularly for meetings, training, or other business purposes, and can modify or revoke the remote work arrangement with reasonable notice.

Hybrid: The employee's work arrangement consists of a combination of on-site and remote work. The employee is required to be present at the employer’s office or premises for a specified number of days per week and may work remotely on the remaining days, in accordance with employer policies and business requirements. The employer has the right to adjust or cancel the hybrid arrangement with reasonable notice. The standards of performance, conduct, and other employment terms remain unchanged regardless of work location.

name: Workplace Location
description: This parameter specifies the primary physical address, site, or facility at which the employee is expected to perform the majority of their duties. This location may be an office, factory, warehouse, branch, or any other business premises of the employer. It serves as the employee’s main place of work under the contract, providing a clear and specific reference point for where the employee is ordinarily based.

name: Workplace Reasonable Mobility
description:
This parameter defines the geographical boundary within which the Employer may require the Employee to perform their duties beyond their normal workplace. This area is set to ensure that any alternative or additional workplaces assigned by the Employer remain within a distance that is reasonable for commuting, consistent with industry standards and the Employee’s role.

This parameter provides clarity and contractual certainty about the extent of the Employee’s mobility obligations. It may encompass part of a city, an entire metropolitan area, or another specifically designated region, depending on the nature of the employment and operational needs. The intention is to balance the Employer’s need for flexibility with the Employee’s expectation of a predictable and manageable commute.

name: Remote Work Modification and Cancellation Right
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employer retains the right to unilaterally modify or revoke the Employee’s remote work arrangement, subject to providing reasonable notice. When this parameter is set to true, remote work is not a guaranteed or permanent condition of employment. The Employer may, at its sole discretion, require the Employee to resume work at the Employer’s premises or change the terms of the remote work arrangement as business needs evolve.

Importantly, activating this parameter does not affect the Employee’s core terms and conditions of employment. The Employee’s salary, benefits, duties, and other contractual rights and obligations remain unchanged regardless of whether work is performed remotely or onsite. This ensures clarity that remote work is a conditional benefit granted at the Employer’s discretion, maintaining flexibility for operational changes while protecting the fundamental terms of employment.

name: Hybrid On-Site Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the minimum amount of time the Employee is required to be physically present at the Employer’s office or on-site location as part of a hybrid work arrangement.

This parameter defines the required on-site attendance duration within a specified time unit (e.g., hours per week, days per month), balancing in-person collaboration and remote work flexibility.

It sets clear expectations for the Employee’s physical presence, supporting team interaction, direct supervision, participation in meetings, and other workplace activities that benefit from face-to-face engagement.

The duration is typically coordinated with the Employer’s operational requirements and policies to ensure alignment with business continuity and productivity goals.

This parameter also promotes a structured hybrid work model that enhances accountability while accommodating employee preferences for remote work.

Default: A common default value is 2 days per week, reflecting a widely accepted hybrid schedule that includes significant remote work flexibility balanced with regular on-site engagement.

name: Hybrid On-Site Duration Unit
description:
This parameter specifies the unit of time used to measure the required minimum duration the Employee must be physically present on-site under a hybrid work arrangement.

This unit defines how the required on-site attendance is calculated, such as per day, per week, or per month, providing a clear standard for measuring attendance obligations.

The parameter ensures precise communication of the expected frequency or amount of on-site work in a hybrid model, making it easy to set, monitor, and enforce attendance requirements aligned with business needs.

It complements the employment_hybrid_onsite_duration parameter by contextualizing the numeric value into a measurable timeframe, improving clarity for the Employee and Employer alike.

Common units reflect typical work schedules and operational cycles and can be adapted to suit diverse organizational policies or roles.

Default: A common default value for this parameter is week, which aligns with standard workweek scheduling and expectations in many hybrid work arrangements.

name: Hybrid Work Modification and Cancellation Right
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employer reserves the right to modify or revoke the Employee’s hybrid work arrangement at its sole discretion, provided reasonable notice is given to the Employee.

When this parameter is set to true, the hybrid working arrangement—where the Employee splits their time between onsite and remote work—is not guaranteed as a permanent condition of employment. The Employer may change or withdraw the hybrid policy as business needs require, including requiring the Employee to work additional days onsite or return to a full onsite schedule.

Importantly, any adjustment or cancellation of the hybrid arrangement under this parameter will not affect the Employee’s other core terms and conditions of employment, such as salary, benefits, responsibilities, or other contractual rights and obligations. The Employee is also expected to maintain the same level of professionalism and job performance regardless of their work location.

name: Mobility, Travel and Relocation
description:
This parameter determines whether the Employee’s role includes a contractual obligation to undertake reasonable business travel or relocate as required by the Employer. When set to true, this parameter activates specific provisions in the employment contract, stating that:
- The Employee acknowledges their duties may require occasional business travel or relocation.
- The Employer must provide reasonable notice if there is a change in the primary place of work or if business travel is necessary.
- Any permanent relocation of the Employee’s primary workplace takes place only after prior consultation, and, where relevant, according to the Employer’s formal relocation policy.
- The Employer provides support and compensation for approved relocations, in line with company policy, and reimburses reasonable work-related travel expenses as per the Employer's expense policy.

This parameter ensures that both parties understand the potential for business-related travel or moves, the process for implementing any relocation, and the Employee’s right to support and reimbursement under such circumstances. It gives the Employer flexibility to respond to operational needs while protecting the Employee with reasonable notice, consultation, and policy-backed compensation.

name: Salary Amount Type
description:
This parameter specifies how the Employee's salary is defined and structured in the employment contract.

annual: The Employee's total salary is stated as an annual amount, which accrues on a daily basis during employment and is paid in equal monthly installments, usually at the end of each calendar month.

monthly: The Employee's salary is specified as a fixed amount per month, accruing daily and paid, in arrears, at the end of each calendar month.

This parameter is used to clearly indicate whether compensation is calculated and presented as a yearly total or as set monthly payments, helping both Employer and Employee understand the basis for salary calculation and payment scheduling.

name: Annual Salary Amount
description:
This parameter specifies the total annual salary payable by the Employer to the Employee under the terms of employment. The amount includes the currency denomination, clearly defining the full yearly compensation agreed upon.

Total Annual Salary with Currency: The annual salary is expressed as a fixed monetary amount in the applicable currency (e.g., USD, EUR, GBP). This total figure represents the full remuneration earned by the Employee over a 12-month period, exclusive of benefits, bonuses, or allowances unless otherwise stated.

Daily Accrual Basis: The salary accrues daily over the entire term of employment, meaning that the Employee earns their annual salary on a pro-rata basis each day they are employed.

Payment Method and Frequency: The salary is paid in equal monthly installments, calculated by dividing the total annual salary by 12. Payments are made in arrears, generally on or around the last day of each calendar month.

Payment Mechanism: All salary payments shall be made by direct bank transfer to the Employee’s nominated bank account, ensuring secure, timely, and traceable salary disbursement.

Purpose and Importance:
Clarity of Compensation: Specifies the agreed pay the Employee will receive for their services annually, providing transparency and contractual certainty.

Consistent Payment Schedule: Monthly payment in arrears aligns with common payroll practices, supporting financial planning for both parties.

Legal and Accounting Compliance: Daily accrual ensures proper handling of salary if employment starts or ends mid-month or mid-year.

Employee Convenience and Security: Direct bank transfers simplify administration and reduce risks associated with cash payments or delayed salary receipt.

Considerations:
The currency used should match the contract’s governing jurisdiction or agreed payment currency to avoid confusion.
Annual salary amount may exclude taxes, social security contributions, or other statutory deductions, which should be clarified elsewhere in the Agreement.

name: Monthly Salary Amount
description:
This parameter specifies the fixed monthly salary payable by the Employer to the Employee under the terms of employment. The amount includes the currency denomination, clearly defining the monthly compensation agreed upon.

Monthly Salary with Currency: The monthly salary is expressed as a fixed monetary amount in the applicable currency (e.g., USD, EUR, GBP). It represents the remuneration the Employee earns each calendar month during the term of employment.

Daily Accrual Basis: The salary accrues daily over the course of the employment period, which means that the Employee earns their monthly salary on a pro-rata basis for each day worked.

Payment Frequency and Timing: Salary payments are made in arrears, typically on or about the last day of each calendar month.

Purpose and Importance:
Clarity in Compensation: Clearly defines the recurring monthly payment amount to the Employee, providing certainty and transparency.
Accurate Proration: Daily accrual ensures correct salary calculation if employment starts or ends mid-month.

Considerations: The currency should match the governing law or agreed payment terms to avoid ambiguity.

name: Daily Salary Rate
description:
This parameter specifies the fixed wage amount the Employee will receive for each day worked. This daily rate reflects the agreed compensation payable on a per-day basis rather than as a fixed monthly or annual salary.
The Employee’s remuneration is calculated strictly based on the actual number of days worked during the pay period. This structure is commonly used for part-time, casual, or temporary employment where the number of workdays can vary.

name: Hourly Salary Rate
description:
This parameter specifies the fixed hourly wage payable by the Employer to the Employee for each hour worked. The amount includes the currency denomination, clearly defining the hourly compensation agreed upon.

Hourly Rate with Currency: The hourly wage is expressed as a fixed monetary amount in the applicable currency (e.g., USD, EUR, GBP). This figure represents the remuneration the Employee earns for each hour of work performed.

Payment Frequency and Timing: Payments for hours worked are made in arrears, generally on or about the last day of each calendar month.

Payment Method: All payments shall be made by direct transfer to the Employee’s nominated bank account, ensuring secure, timely, and traceable salary disbursement.

Purpose and Importance: 
Clear Compensation Terms: Defines the exact hourly pay rate to the Employee, providing transparency and contractual certainty.
Flexible Payment Based on Actual Hours Worked: Suitable for roles with variable or part-time hours, ensuring the Employee is compensated accurately for time worked.
Consistent Payment Schedule: Monthly payment in arrears aligns with typical payroll cycles, supporting predictable income.
Secure and Efficient Payment Method: Direct bank transfer minimizes risks related to delays or errors in salary payments.

Considerations: The currency should align with the contract’s governing jurisdiction or agreed payment terms.

name: Salary Amount Basis (Gross or Net)
description:
This parameter specifies whether the stated salary amount is expressed as a gross or net figure:

Gross: When set to gross, the salary amount refers to the total sum before any taxes, social security contributions, and other statutory or contractual deductions are applied. The Employee’s take-home pay will be less than the stated gross salary, after all required deductions.

Net: When set to net, the salary amount reflects the actual amount payable to the Employee after all legally required taxes, deductions, and withholdings have been subtracted. This is the Employee’s final take-home salary.

name: No Overtime and Additional Payment
description:
parameter indicates whether the Employee’s stated salary fully compensates them for all hours worked, including overtime, statutory holidays, and weekends, without entitlement to extra payments.

true: The salary provided to the Employee is deemed full and final compensation for all hours worked during normal and extended working times. This means that, unless explicitly agreed otherwise in writing, the Employee is not entitled to additional pay for overtime hours, weekend work, or work on statutory holidays. Any further bonuses, premiums, or additional payments remain at the Employer’s sole discretion and must be separately agreed.

false: The standard salary is subject to additional compensation provisions, meaning the Employee may be entitled to receive extra payments for overtime, weekends, or statutory holidays in accordance with applicable law, company policy, or specific contractual arrangements.

name: Annual Salary Review (Employer Discretion)
description:
parameter indicates whether the Employee’s salary review and any subsequent increase are made solely at the Employer’s discretion.

true: The Employee’s salary will be reviewed annually; however, any salary increase remains entirely at the Employer’s discretion. There is no obligation on the Employer to grant a raise. Additionally, any increase implemented will not alter other terms of employment. Salary reviews or increases will not occur once either party has given notice of termination. This parameter clarifies that salary adjustments are not guaranteed and depend on the Employer’s assessment and decision.

false: The salary review paragraph referencing discretionary increases shall not appear in the employment agreement. This implies either no formal salary review is provided, or salary adjustments may be governed by other non-discretionary terms not covered by this clause.

name: Recovery of Debts from Salary
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employer is contractually entitled to deduct amounts owed by the Employee from their salary or other payments.

true: The Employer has the right to deduct any debts or amounts owed by the Employee (e.g., advances, overpayments, costs for damaged company property) directly from the Employee’s salary or other payments due to them. Such deductions must always comply with applicable laws and regulations regarding salary deductions.

false: The clause granting the Employer the explicit right to deduct debts from the Employee’s salary or other payments shall not appear in the employment agreement. This means that if the Employee owes the Employer money, the Employer may need to pursue other legal avenues for recovery, as direct salary deductions for debts would not be contractually permitted under this agreement.

name: Incentive Compensation Clause
description:
This parameter controls the inclusion of an Incentive Compensation clause in the employment agreement.

When enabled (set to true), the employment contract incorporates provisions related to various incentive payments such as signing bonuses, retention bonuses, personal and company performance bonuses, project completion bonuses, and sales commissions.

The clause defines eligibility criteria, payment timing, conditions for earning bonuses or commissions, and any repayment obligations if employment ends prematurely.

It also covers employer discretionary rights regarding adjustment, withholding, or rescinding of incentive payments. It also clarifies tax treatment and specifies that incentive compensation is typically non-pensionable.

Including this clause aligns employee compensation with individual, team, or corporate performance targets and incentivizes desired behaviors and retention.

When disabled (set to false), no incentive compensation provisions are included in the employment agreement, making the employee’s compensation strictly fixed or salary-based without bonus or commission components.

name: Signing Bonus
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a Signing Bonus clause.

When set to true, the contract specifies a one-time signing bonus amount payable to the employee within a defined period after the employee’s start date. The signing bonus is conditional upon the employee’s continuous employment for a minimum specified period.
If the employee’s employment ends before completing this period, the employee must repay the full signing bonus amount to the employer.

The clause acts as an incentive to attract new employees and encourages commitment to remain employed with the company for the agreed duration. Including this clause helps protect the employer’s financial investment by ensuring the signing bonus rewards sustained employment rather than short-term tenure.

When set to false, no signing bonus provisions are included in the employment contract.

name: Signing Bonus Amount
description:
This parameter specifies the monetary value of the one-time signing bonus payable to the employee upon commencement of employment.
The amount defined here is the total sum the employee will receive as a signing incentive, subject to the terms set forth in the signing bonus clause.
The payment of this bonus is typically made within a specified time frame after the employee’s start date.
The signing bonus amount is contingent upon the employee maintaining continuous employment for a minimum period; otherwise, repayment obligations may apply.

name: Signing Bonus Payment Duration
description:
This parameter defines the time period within which the one-time signing bonus must be paid to the employee following their commencement date.
It establishes a clear deadline for the employer to disburse the signing bonus after the employee starts work.
The payment duration helps manage expectations for both the employee and employer regarding when the bonus will be received.
Specifying this duration ensures timely payment and reduces potential disputes related to bonus disbursement delays.

name: Signing Bonus Employment Period
description:
This parameter specifies the minimum continuous employment duration the employee must complete to retain the full signing bonus without obligation to repay.
It establishes the required length of service following commencement during which the signing bonus remains earned and non-repayable.
If the employee’s employment terminates for any reason before this period elapses, they must repay the full signing bonus amount to the employer as per the signing bonus clause.
Setting this employment period protects the employer’s investment by encouraging employee retention and commitment for a defined term.
The parameter provides clear expectations regarding the consequences of early employment termination related to the bonus.
A default duration of 12 months is commonly used, balancing employer protection with reasonable employee commitment.

name: Retention Bonus
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a Retention Bonus clause.
When enabled (set to true), the contract provides that the employee may be eligible for a retention bonus payable upon completion of a specified continuous employment period. The retention bonus acts as an incentive for the employee to remain with the employer for the duration required. 
The clause typically includes conditions that if the employee voluntarily resigns or is terminated for cause before the completion of the retention period, the bonus is forfeited.
It may also include provisions requiring repayment of any retention bonus paid if employment ends prematurely under certain conditions. Including this clause encourages employee loyalty and workforce stability by rewarding long-term commitment.
When disabled (set to false), the employment agreement excludes any provisions related to retention bonuses.

name: Retention Bonus Amount
description:
This parameter specifies the monetary value of the retention bonus that an employee may receive upon successfully completing the required continuous employment period.
It defines the exact sum offered as an incentive to encourage long-term commitment to the employer.
Setting this amount allows clear definition of the financial reward tied to employee retention within the employment agreement.

name: Retention Bonus Duration
description:
This parameter defines the required continuous employment period the employee must complete to be eligible for the retention bonus.
It specifies the minimum length of service after the employee’s start date during which the retention bonus remains payable.
If the employee resigns voluntarily or is terminated for cause before completing this period, the retention bonus will be forfeited.
Setting this duration aligns the retention bonus incentive with the employer’s goal of promoting employee stability and long-term commitment.
The parameter helps establish clear expectations regarding the timing and eligibility conditions for earning the retention bonus.
A default duration of 12 months is commonly applied to balance retention incentives with reasonable employment tenure expectations.

name: Personal Performance Bonus
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a Personal Performance Bonus clause.

When enabled (set to true), the contract grants the employee eligibility to receive a bonus based on the achievement of individual performance objectives set during a specified review period. The clause incentivizes employees to meet or exceed their personal work goals, fostering motivation and productivity.
Payment of the bonus is contingent upon successful attainment of the pre-established performance targets.
Including this clause aligns employee efforts with company performance expectations and recognizes individual contributions.

When disabled (set to false), the employment agreement excludes any provisions related to personal performance bonuses.

name: Performance Review Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the time frame during which the employee’s personal performance objectives are evaluated for bonus eligibility.
It defines the period over which performance is measured, commonly aligning with annual review cycles.
The review period establishes the schedule for setting goals, assessing achievements, and determining bonus payments tied to individual performance.
Setting this parameter ensures clarity on when performance targets are relevant and when bonus eligibility is assessed.
It supports structured performance management processes and transparent communication of expectations.
A typical default value is 12 months, but this can be adjusted based on company review practices or specific role requirements.

name: Company Performance Bonus
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a Company Performance Bonus clause.

When enabled (set to true), the contract provides that the employee may receive a bonus contingent upon the employer achieving specified corporate targets during a fiscal year.
The employee must typically be employed for the entire fiscal year to qualify for this bonus.
This clause encourages employees to contribute to the overall success and financial goals of the company.

When disabled (set to false), the employment agreement excludes any clauses related to company performance bonuses.

name: Project Completion Bonus
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a Project Completion Bonus clause.
When set to true, the contract entitles the employee to a bonus upon the satisfactory and timely completion of a designated project according to specified requirements and deadlines. The clause incentivizes employees to deliver quality work on time and meet project goals. It aligns employee rewards with successful project outcomes, enhancing accountability and motivation.
When disabled (set to false), no project completion bonus provisions are included in the agreement.

name: Project Completion Bonus Amount
description:
This parameter specifies the monetary value of the bonus awarded to the employee upon successful completion of a designated project.
It defines the exact financial reward tied to meeting project specifications, quality standards, and deadlines.
The amount serves as an incentive to motivate timely and satisfactory project delivery.
This parameter enables precise customization of compensation packages to recognize project-based achievements according to company policies.

name: Project Name for Completion Bonus
description:
This parameter specifies the name or identification of the project tied to the employee’s project completion bonus eligibility.
It clearly defines which specific project must be satisfactorily completed to qualify for the associated bonus.
Naming the project provides clarity and focus, ensuring both parties understand the scope and expectations linked to the bonus.
This prevents ambiguity about which project milestones or deliverables trigger the bonus payment.

name: Project Deadline for Completion Bonus
description:
This parameter sets the specific deadline by which the designated project must be completed to qualify for the project completion bonus.
It establishes a clear target date to ensure timely delivery aligned with the terms of the bonus.
Defining the project deadline helps prevent misunderstandings about when the project must be finished to earn the bonus.
The deadline incentivizes employees to meet project timelines, supporting effective project management and organizational goals.

name: Sales Commission Type
description:
This parameter defines the type of sales commission the Employee is eligible to receive, with two possible values: flat or tiered.

Flat Sales Commission
The Employee earns a fixed percentage of the gross revenue generated from sales directly attributable to them. The commission amount is calculated by applying a single commission rate to all qualifying sales revenue. Commissions are payable within a specified period following the end of the relevant calculation time unit (such as a month or quarter) when the revenue is recognized. This method offers simplicity and straightforward calculation for sales compensation.

Tiered Sales Commission
The Employee’s commission is calculated using a tiered structure based on sales thresholds. Commissions rates vary depending on the range of sales achieved:

Sales up to the first threshold earn a base commission rate.

Sales exceeding the first threshold but within the second threshold earn a higher or different rate on that specific portion.

Sales beyond the second threshold earn the highest commission rate for the excess amount.
This tiered approach incentivizes higher sales levels with increasing commission rates as sales volume grows. Commissions are payable within the designated payment duration following the end of the calculation period.

name: Sales Commission Percentage
description:
This parameter specifies the percentage rate applied to the gross revenue generated from sales directly attributable to the employee to calculate their sales commission.

It defines the portion of sales revenue that the employee will earn as a commission, serving as a direct incentive for sales performance.

The commission percentage is a key component of variable compensation plans designed to motivate employees to increase sales and align their goals with company revenue objectives.

A defined commission rate ensures clear and consistent calculation of commission payments within the terms of the employment agreement.

Setting this parameter allows organizations to tailor compensation structures to industry standards, competitive practices, and specific role responsibilities.

Commission payments based on this percentage are typically made within a specified period following the end of the revenue recognition period, ensuring timely reward for sales efforts.

The value can vary widely depending on the industry, product margin, sales cycle, and overall compensation strategy, ranging commonly from 5% to 20% or more of sales revenue.

name: Sales Commission Payment Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the time period within which the sales commission payments must be made to the employee following the end of the revenue recognition or sales calculation period.

It defines the maximum allowable delay between the close of the sales period and when the employee receives their earned commissions, ensuring timely compensation.

The duration can vary depending on organizational policies, financial processing cycles, and contractual agreements.

Setting this parameter helps provide clarity and predictability regarding the timing of commission payouts, supporting employee financial planning and motivation.

This period often accounts for administrative processes such as confirming sales revenue, adjusting for returns or chargebacks, and finalizing payroll.

Clearly defined payment duration protects both the employee’s rights to compensation and the employer's operational needs for accurate commission calculation and payment.

Typical values range from immediate payment upon period end up to 60 days, with 30 days being a common standard.

name: Sales Commission Calculation Time Unit
description:
This parameter defines the time unit or period over which sales revenue is measured and commissions are calculated.

It determines the interval at the end of which sales performance is assessed for commission eligibility and payment calculations.

Common time units include monthly, quarterly, or annually, depending on the company’s sales cycles and commission structure.

Setting this parameter ensures clarity on the revenue recognition period relevant for commission calculations, avoiding ambiguity in timing and payment schedules.

It facilitates aligning commission payments with accounting and financial reporting periods of the employer.

The parameter supports consistent tracking and fair remuneration of sales efforts over regular intervals, motivating ongoing performance.

Clear definition of this time unit helps streamline commission processing and employee understanding of compensation timing.

name: Tier 1 Sales Commission Threshold
description:
This parameter defines the maximum sales amount or revenue up to which the first tier commission rate applies in a tiered sales commission structure.

It represents the sales performance level at which the initial, typically lower, commission rate is calculated.

Sales amounts up to this threshold qualify for the Tier 1 commission rate, providing a baseline incentive for entry-level sales achievements.

Setting this threshold helps structure the tiered commission schedule by creating defined revenue brackets for diverse commission rates.

A clear Tier 1 threshold motivates employees to reach initial sales targets and serves as a stepping stone to higher commission tiers.

The threshold value is adjustable to align with company sales goals, product pricing, and compensation strategies.

name: Tier 1 Sales Commission Rate
description:
This parameter specifies the commission rate applied to sales amounts that fall within the first tier or threshold in a tiered commission structure.

It determines the percentage of sales revenue earned as commission for sales up to the Tier 1 threshold.

This rate is typically the base or entry-level commission rate designed to provide initial incentive for achieving sales targets.

Adjusting this parameter allows organizations to set competitive and motivating initial commission levels aligned with their sales strategy.

The Tier 1 commission rate encourages consistent sales performance by rewarding foundational sales efforts.

It forms part of the tiered schedule where higher commission rates may apply to sales exceeding this tier, incentivizing increased sales volume.

name: Tier 2 Sales Commission Threshold
description:
This parameter defines the maximum sales amount or revenue up to which the second tier commission rate applies in a tiered sales commission structure.

It sets the upper limit of the second sales bracket, where a distinct commission rate is applied to sales amounts that exceed the first tier threshold but do not exceed this second threshold.

Sales between the first and second thresholds qualify for the Tier 2 commission rate, which is typically higher than the Tier 1 rate to incentivize increased sales performance.

Setting this threshold helps establish clear boundaries for commission calculations, encouraging sales growth beyond the initial threshold.

The Tier 2 threshold is adjustable to align with company sales goals, product pricing, and compensation strategies.

Defining this parameter provides transparency and motivation for sales employees to surpass baseline targets and reach higher performance levels.

name: Tier 2 Sales Commission Rate
description:
This parameter specifies the commission rate applied to sales amounts that fall within the second tier, between the first and second sales thresholds, in a tiered commission structure.

It defines the percentage of sales revenue earned as commission for sales exceeding the first tier threshold but not exceeding the second tier threshold.

The Tier 2 commission rate is usually higher than the Tier 1 rate, serving as an incentive to encourage sales beyond the initial target.

Adjusting this rate allows companies to motivate sales growth with progressive rewards while aligning commission costs with business goals.

The parameter is a key component in structuring escalating commission plans that reward increasing performance with higher commission percentages.

name: Tier 3 Sales Commission Rate
description:
This parameter specifies the commission rate applied to sales amounts that exceed the second tier threshold in a tiered commission structure.

It defines the percentage of sales revenue earned as commission for sales beyond the upper limit of the second tier.

Typically, the Tier 3 rate is the highest commission percentage in the tiered schedule, designed to strongly incentivize exceptional sales performance.

Setting this rate encourages sales employees to surpass baseline and intermediate targets, pushing for top-tier achievements and higher revenue generation.

This parameter plays a crucial role in structuring progressive commission plans that reward increased sales with escalating commission rates.

name: Residual Commission
description:
This boolean parameter indicates whether the employee is entitled to receive residual commissions on recurring revenue generated from clients or accounts they originally procured.

Residual commissions provide ongoing income for salespeople based on a percentage of recurring revenue, extending beyond the initial sale.

Such commissions are common in subscription-based, service, or contract-renewal industries where customers make repeated purchases or payments.

Enabling this parameter means the employee continues to earn commissions for a defined duration following the initial sale, incentivizing long-term client relationship management and retention.

Commissions under this structure are payable within a specified time frame following the end of the revenue recognition period to ensure timely compensation.

name: Residual Commission Percentage
description:
This parameter defines the percentage rate of recurring revenue generated from clients or accounts initially procured by the employee that is paid to the employee as residual commission.

It represents the portion of ongoing income from those clients for which the employee continues to earn commission beyond the initial sale.

Residual commission percentages provide long-term incentive for employees to maintain client relationships and support continued business.

The percentage is typically applied to recurring revenue streams such as renewals, subscriptions, or service contracts.

Defining this parameter ensures clear, consistent calculation of residual commissions and aligns employee rewards with sustained client revenue.

This component of compensation encourages sustained engagement and supports retention of valuable customers over time.

name: Residual Commission Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the duration or period following the initial sale during which the employee is entitled to receive residual commissions from recurring revenue generated by clients or accounts they procured.

It determines how long the residual commission payments will continue, incentivizing the employee to maintain client relationships and support ongoing business over a set term.

The duration may be expressed in months or years, depending on the company’s compensation policy and the nature of the sales or subscription cycle.

Clearly defining this duration helps set expectations for commission payments and aligns incentives with long-term customer retention efforts.

Proper configuration ensures fair compensation tied to the sustained value of clients, fostering loyalty and consistent revenue streams.

name: Residual Commission Payment Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the time frame within which residual commissions are paid to the Employee following the end of the defined revenue calculation period (e.g., monthly, quarterly).

This duration governs how quickly the Employee receives their residual commission payments after the Employer recognizes recurring revenue generated from clients or accounts originally procured by the Employee.

Residual commissions represent ongoing payments for recurring revenue and are not one-time commissions; thus, clear payment timing is critical for predictable and fair compensation.

The payment duration ensures administrative processing time while setting expectations for timely remuneration to motivate and retain Employees.

Employers often align this payment duration with accounting cycles or billing terms to match revenue recognition and avoid payment discrepancies.

Example: If residual commissions are calculated quarterly and the payment duration is 30 days, the commission for the revenue recognized in Q1 will be paid within 30 days after the quarter ends.

Defining the payment duration in the employment agreement or commission plan provides transparency, helps manage cash flows and aligns incentives with ongoing business performance.

The parameter supports efficient payroll operations, reconciliations, and reduces disputes by clearly stating when commissions are due.

Timely payment of residual commissions can enhance Employee satisfaction, encourage long-term customer retention efforts, and improve overall sales performance.

name: Residual Commission Calculation Time Unit
description:
This parameter defines the time unit over which residual commissions are calculated and paid to the Employee.

Residual commissions represent ongoing earnings based on a percentage of recurring revenue generated from clients or accounts initially procured by the Employee.

The "calculation time unit" determines the period after which the relevant revenue is recognized and upon which commission payments are based. Common time units include monthly, quarterly, or annually.

Commissions become payable within a specified time (such as 15 or 30 days) following the close of the defined calculation period, ensuring timely and predictable payment cycles.

Choosing an appropriate time unit aligns commission payments with the Employer’s billing cycles and revenue recognition practices.

It assists in accurately tracing and attributing recurring revenue streams to the Employee's original sales activities on a consistent schedule.

The parameter supports transparency and clarity in commission calculations, enabling both Employer and Employee to manage expectations about payment timing and amounts.

By defining a clear calculation period, it helps avoid disputes related to commission timing and ensures compliance with internal financial controls and payroll regulations.

The residual commission is typically paid as a percentage of recurring revenue realized within each calculation period, multiplied by the commission rate.

This system incentivizes the Employee to maintain long-term client relationships, as commissions continue based on the longevity and volume of recurring revenue over the defined calculation periods.

name: Team Sales Commission
description:
This parameter indicates whether the employee is eligible to receive a commission based on the total sales or revenue generated by their designated team or group.

When enabled, the employee earns a percentage commission of the collective sales performance of the team as defined by the employer.

The specific definition of the team and eligible sales is determined at the employer's discretion, allowing flexibility in team composition and coverage.

Commissions under this structure are payable within a specified period following the end of the sales commission calculation time unit to ensure timely remuneration.

This parameter promotes collaboration and collective success among team members, aligning individual incentives with group performance.

Enabling team commissions can enhance motivation, foster cooperation, and drive overall sales productivity in team-based selling environments.

It supports compensation strategies aimed at rewarding both individual effort and team contributions within the sales function.

name: Team Commission Percentage
description:
This parameter defines the percentage of the total sales or revenue generated by the employee’s designated team or group that the employee is eligible to receive as commission.

It specifies the rate at which team-based sales contribute to the employee’s commission earnings under a team commission structure.

The parameter enables rewarding employees for the collective success of their team, encouraging collaboration and shared accountability for sales performance.

The percentage is set by the employer based on the specific sales compensation strategy and the role of the employee within the team.

Clear definition of this parameter helps ensure transparent and consistent calculation of team commissions, aligning incentives with group performance goals.

name: Team Commission Payment Duration
description:
This parameter defines the specific time frame within which the Employer will pay commissions to the Employee based on the total sales or revenue generated by the Employee’s designated team or group.

It sets a clear deadline for commission payments following the close of the predefined commission calculation period (e.g., monthly or quarterly).

The payment duration ensures timely and consistent disbursement of earned commissions, allowing for financial planning and operational cash flow management both for the Employer and the Employee.

Defining this period supports transparency and fairness in compensation schemes by creating predictable payment timelines linked to actual revenue recognition.

The time frame is typically structured to allow for the processing of sales data, verification of revenue, and handling of possible adjustments such as returns or cancellations before the commission is finalized and paid.

Clarifying the payment duration helps manage employee expectations and reduces disputes related to commission payments.

It aligns commission payments with accounting and payroll cycles, ensuring compliance with internal financial controls and legal payroll requirements.

The Employer retains discretion to define or adjust the payment duration as necessary, based on operational needs or changes in business practices, subject to contract terms.

This provision incentivizes teamwork and collective performance by linking the commission payout to the group’s overall success within a specified time frame after revenue has been realized.

name: Team Commission Calculation Time Unit
description:
This parameter defines the period over which the sales or revenue generated by the Employee’s designated team or group is calculated to determine the commission payout.

The "calculation time unit" is the time frame (e.g., month, quarter) in which the Employer recognizes the revenue generated by the team, serving as the basis for commission calculations.

Commissions are paid within a specified duration (e.g., 15 or 30 days) following the end of this calculation period, ensuring regular and predictable commission payments.

Setting an appropriate time unit aligns commission payments with the Employer's financial and sales reporting cycles, improving accounting accuracy and operational consistency.

It aids in fairly attributing team-generated revenue to commission payments within well-defined intervals, facilitating transparency and clarity in compensation.

This parameter helps synchronize payroll and commission systems to avoid miscalculations or payment delays related to variable sales periods.

By defining the time unit, the Employer sets expectations for when commissions are earned and payable based on team performance during that period.

The structure incentivizes teamwork and sustained performance by measuring collective sales success over consistent, recurring periods.
