The team’s definition and eligible sales subject to this commission calculation are determined by the Employer, ensuring flexibility in commission policy implementation.

name: Deal/Transaction Commission
description:
This parameter indicates whether the employee is entitled to receive a fixed commission amount for each individual deal or transaction they successfully close.

Commission is payable only upon the employer’s receipt of full payment from the customer or client related to the completed deal, ensuring commissions are based on realized revenue.

Payments of deal commissions occur within a specified timeframe following confirmation of the completed transaction and receipt of payment, providing timely compensation.

This parameter supports commission structures that focus on rewarding sales volume by deal count rather than percentage of sales revenue.

Enabling this parameter aligns employee incentives with closing deals promptly and securing full payment, enhancing sales effectiveness and cash flow certainty for the employer.

It provides a clear and straightforward incentive mechanism for sales roles where deal completion is a key performance metric.

name: Deal Commission Amount
description:
This parameter specifies the fixed monetary amount that an employee is entitled to receive as commission for each successfully closed deal or transaction.

The commission amount is payable only upon the employer’s receipt of full payment from the related customer or client, ensuring commission payouts are based on confirmed revenue.

Payment of the deal commission is made within a defined period following confirmation of the completed transaction and receipt of payment, offering timely compensation.

Setting this amount supports compensation plans focusing on rewarding the quantity of deals closed rather than a percentage of sales value.

This clear, fixed-value commission incentivizes employees to close more transactions, aligning rewards directly with deal completion and payment collection.

The parameter allows organizations to implement straightforward, predictable commission models suitable for roles emphasizing deal closure volume.

name: Incentive Compensation Non-Pensionable
description:
This boolean parameter indicates whether incentive payments or amounts payable under the corresponding provision are excluded from the employee's pensionable remuneration.

When set to true, the specified payments will not contribute to the calculation of pension benefits or pension contributions for the employee.

These non-pensionable amounts are also excluded from statutory remuneration calculations which may affect social security, insurance, or other statutory benefits linked to pensionable earnings.

Such exclusions typically apply to bonuses, commissions, or other incentive payments that are variable, discretionary, or non-regular in nature.

By excluding these amounts from pensionable remuneration, the future pension benefits tied to salary or earnings bases will not increase due to these incentive payments.

This parameter helps employers clearly define the nature of incentive payments in compensation packages, supporting transparent and compliant pension administration.

Employees should be informed when a portion of their compensation is non-pensionable to set proper expectations regarding retirement benefits and statutory contributions.

The decision to classify incentive amounts as non-pensionable is often based on the payment's regularity, definitiveness, and integration into the overall pay structure.

name: Incentive Eligibility
description:
This boolean parameter specifies whether the employee meets the eligibility criteria to receive incentive payments.

The employee must be actively employed on the payment date to qualify for receiving incentive payments.

The employee must not be subject to any disciplinary action or be under a performance improvement plan (PIP) at the time of payment.

Continuous employment through the payment date is required unless there is an alternative written agreement.

This ensures that incentive payments reward only employees who maintain satisfactory conduct and performance up to and including the payment date.

The provision prevents payments to employees who have resigned, been terminated, or are undergoing disciplinary or performance-related interventions at payment time.

It aligns incentive compensation with sustained employment and behavioral standards, encouraging ongoing compliance and performance.

The parameter may be overridden or waived only through explicit written consent from the employer.

name: Employer Discretion on Incentive Compensation
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employer has sole and absolute discretion over incentive payments to the employee.

The Employer may determine, adjust, withhold, reduce, or rescind any incentive payments, whether in whole or in part, at its discretion.

Such discretion may be exercised based on factors including employee conduct, adherence to company policies, performance levels, and correctness of commission or payment calculations.

The Employer can also consider transaction-related factors such as chargebacks, refunds, cancellations, or similar deductions when exercising discretion.

Payments may be withheld temporarily pending the outcome of investigations or adjustments related to any of these issues.

This discretionary power allows the Employer to manage risk, ensure fairness, and protect company interests regarding incentive compensation.

The discretion must be exercised in good faith, fairly, and not arbitrarily or capriciously to avoid legal challenges.

Employees should be aware that incentive payments are not guaranteed and are subject to the Employer’s judgment and ongoing compliance with company policies.

This parameter formalizes the Employer’s right to control incentive payouts dynamically, aligning compensation with business conditions and employee behavior.

name: Incentive Payment Taxation
description:
If True (Payments are subject to applicable taxes):

All incentive payments made to the employee are subject to taxation as required by applicable laws.

Taxes such as income tax, payroll tax, social security contributions, and other statutory deductions may be withheld by the employer before payment.

Employees will receive net payments after all mandatory tax deductions, which can vary depending on jurisdiction and tax regulations.

This ensures compliance with local and national tax authorities and avoids tax liabilities for both employer and employee.

Employees should understand that the gross incentive amount will be reduced by applicable taxes before payment.

If False (Payments are not subject to applicable taxes):

Incentive payments are disbursed to employees without withholding tax deductions at the time of payment.

Employees may be required to report and pay taxes on these incentives independently when filing tax returns, depending on jurisdiction.

Employers may still have reporting obligations to tax authorities regarding the total incentive paid.

This scenario might apply in jurisdictions where taxation is settled by employees or in cases of gross-up arrangements where employees receive gross incentives with separate tax payments.

Employees and employers should be clear on tax responsibilities to ensure compliance and avoid penalties.

name: Stock-Based Compensation
description:
This boolean parameter specifies whether the employment agreement includes a comprehensive stock-based compensation clause.

When enabled (true), the agreement incorporates provisions for various equity awards such as stock options (ESOP), restricted stock units (RSUs), phantom stock, stock appreciation rights (SARs), and employee stock purchase plans (ESPP).

It outlines terms including grant quantities, exercise prices, vesting schedules, and the employee’s rights and responsibilities concerning these equity instruments.

The clause also addresses important considerations like tax and legal compliance, transfer restrictions, adjustments for corporate actions, and the absence of shareholder rights until shares are issued.

Inclusion of this clause enables formal administration of equity compensation aligned with company plans, providing employees with potential ownership interests or cash equivalents tied to company performance.

When disabled (false), the employment contract does not contain stock compensation provisions, indicating that the employee is not a participant in the employer’s equity award programs.

This parameter helps tailor the employment contract to specific compensation structures, ensuring clarity and legal compliance in equity award arrangements.

name: Employment Stock Compensation ESOP
description:
The employee is granted options to purchase a specific number of shares of the employer’s common stock at a predetermined exercise price.

These options are granted under the terms of the Employer’s Share Option Plan (ESOP) and a separate Grant Agreement.

Options vest and become exercisable according to a schedule outlined in the ESOP and Grant Agreement, typically rewarding employee loyalty and performance over time.

Participation aligns employee interests with company success by providing potential financial gain based on stock price appreciation.

The stock options represent a contractual right, but do not obligate the employee to purchase shares; unexercised options may expire.

ESOP terms, including number of shares, exercise price, vesting, and exercise period, are legally binding and governed by the plan documents.

This form of stock compensation incentivizes employees and enhances retention by offering future ownership stake in the company.

name: Stock Options Quantity
description:
Defines the maximum number of shares the employee is eligible to purchase under the employer’s stock option plan.

Specifies the total quantity of stock options granted to the employee as part of their equity compensation.

Options are granted subject to the terms and conditions of the Employer’s Share Option Plan (ESOP) and a Grant Agreement.

The grant includes the right to purchase company shares at a fixed exercise price within specified timeframes.

Vesting schedules dictate when and how many of these options become exercisable based on continued employment or other criteria.

The quantity sets an upper limit on the shares the employee may acquire through exercising their options.

This parameter is crucial for determining the employee’s potential ownership stake through stock options.

name: Stock Options Exercise Price
description:
The exercise price is the fixed price at which the employee can purchase each share of the employer’s common stock under the stock option plan.

Also known as the strike price, it is typically set at or near the fair market value of the stock at the time the options are granted.

This price remains constant for the duration of the option grant and is used to calculate the cost to exercise the options.

If the market price of the stock rises above the exercise price, the employee benefits by buying shares at a lower price, potentially realizing a gain.

Conversely, if the stock price drops below the exercise price, the options may not be exercised as they are "out of the money."

The exercise price is a key factor in determining the financial value and incentive potential of stock option grants.

Terms related to exercise price, including payment method and timing, are detailed in the ESOP plan and grant agreement.

name: ESOP Documents Attached Confirmation
description:
The Employer’s Employee Stock Option Plan (ESOP) and the related Grant Agreement are included as attachments to the employment agreement.

These documents form an integral part of the overall employment contract, making their terms legally binding on the employee.

The employee confirms receipt, acknowledgment, and understanding of these ESOP documents.

By agreeing to the employment contract, the employee agrees to be bound by all terms and conditions specified in the ESOP and grant agreements.

This clause ensures transparency and clear communication of stock option plan details to the employee.

It formalizes employee commitment to the ESOP provisions alongside other employment terms.

Attachment of these documents aids in compliance, minimizing disputes related to equity compensation terms later.

name: Restricted Stock Units (RSUs)
description:
The employee is granted a specific number of Restricted Stock Units (RSUs), each entitling the employee to receive one share of the employer’s common stock or cash equivalent upon meeting vesting conditions.

RSUs are conditional rights that vest over time or upon achievement of specified performance metrics, as per the employer’s RSU plan.

Vesting is generally contingent upon the employee’s continued service or fulfilling performance goals defined by the plan.

Upon vesting, the RSUs are settled by issuing shares or paying cash based on the employer’s plan terms.

RSUs provide an equity compensation method that aligns the employee’s interests with company performance and retention goals.

The arrangement involves no immediate ownership until the RSUs vest and are converted into shares or cash.

The RSU plan outlines detailed terms on schedule, restrictions, and settlement procedures to govern the awarding and administration of RSUs.

name: Restricted Stock Units (RSU) Quantity
description:
Specifies the number of Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) granted to the employee.

Each RSU represents a conditional right to receive one share of the employer’s common stock or a cash equivalent upon vesting.

Vesting is subject to the employee’s continued service or the satisfaction of performance targets as outlined in the employer’s RSU plan.

Upon vesting, RSUs are settled by issuing shares or paying cash, depending on the terms of the plan.

RSUs provide an equity incentive that aligns employee interests with company success and retention.

The quantity defines the total potential shares or cash value the employee may receive from RSUs over the vesting period.

name: Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP)
description:
The Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP) allows employees to purchase shares of the employer’s stock, often at a discounted price.

Employees typically contribute to the plan through payroll deductions over a set offering period.

On the purchase date, accumulated funds are used to buy company stock on behalf of participating employees.

The discount can be up to 15% below market price, sometimes using a "look-back" provision to use the lower stock price between offering and purchase dates.

ESPPs encourage employee ownership and alignment with company success by providing affordable access to company stock.

Participation is voluntary and subject to plan terms, eligibility, and employer policies.

Taxes on ESPP shares depend on holding periods and plan qualification, with qualified plans offering favorable tax treatment.

ESPPs differ from stock options and other equity awards in structure, taxation, and exercise mechanics.

name: ESPP Discount Percentage
description:
Specifies the percentage discount offered to employees on the purchase price of company stock under the Employee Stock Purchase Plan (ESPP).

Common discounts range from 5% to 15% below the fair market value of shares on the purchase date or the offering date, whichever is lower.

The discount incentivizes employee participation by allowing the purchase of shares at a price lower than the market value.

This discounted price increases the potential financial gain for employees when the stock value rises.

The percentage discount is subject to the terms of the employer’s ESPP and may vary based on plan design.

Applicable tax rules may treat the discount as a taxable benefit, affecting the employee’s tax liability.

The discount percentage is a key factor that enhances the attractiveness of the ESPP as a benefit.

name: Phantom Stock
description:
The employer may grant the employee phantom stock units, which represent a right to receive a cash payment tied to the value of an equivalent number of company shares.

Phantom stock units do not represent actual ownership of company stock but provide financial benefits similar to stock appreciation.

These units vest according to the employer’s terms, which may include a vesting schedule or conditions such as continued employment or performance goals.

Upon vesting, the employee receives a cash payment or other form of consideration equivalent to the fair market value of the specified number of shares.

Phantom stock plans help align employee interests with company performance without diluting equity or transferring actual shares.

This compensation form is flexible, can be granted to various contributors including employees and contractors, and may be used by companies to attract and retain talent.

Phantom stock payouts are usually triggered at vesting, liquidity events, or specified payment dates as defined by the employer.

name: Phantom Stock Units
description:
Represents a contingent right to receive a cash payment equivalent to the fair market value of a specified number of the employer’s common stock shares or equivalent equity interest.

Phantom stock units vest and become payable based on terms and conditions set by the employer, which may include vesting schedules or other performance/service conditions.

Payment for vested units is made in cash or another form of consideration prescribed by the employer on the applicable vesting or payment dates.

Phantom stock provides employees with an equity-linked benefit without transferring actual shares or ownership rights.

This compensation aligns employees’ interests with company performance while preserving company equity and control.

Phantom stock units do not confer voting rights or shareholder privileges to employees.

They serve as a form of long-term incentive and retention tool, rewarding employees based on company value appreciation.

name: Stock Appreciation Rights (SARs)
description:
The employee is granted Stock Appreciation Rights (SARs) tied to a specified number of units at a predetermined grant price.

SARs vest according to a defined schedule, conditioned on continued employment or other agreed criteria.

Upon exercise, the employee receives cash or shares equal to the increase in stock value over the grant price, without needing to buy stock.

SARs provide a way to benefit from stock price appreciation without an upfront purchase cost.

The exercise period limits when vested SARs must be exercised before expiration.

SARs are a long-term incentive designed to align employee interests with company performance and retention.

Terms including grant price, vesting, exercise period, and payout method are governed by the employer’s SAR plan documents.

name: Stock Appreciation Rights (SAR) Number of Units
description:
Specifies the total number of Stock Appreciation Rights (SARs) granted to the employee.

Each unit represents a right to receive compensation equal to the increase in value of a share of the employer’s stock over the grant price.

The number of SAR units determines the potential financial gain available to the employee upon exercise.

SARs vest based on a defined schedule, typically linked to continued employment or performance conditions.

Upon exercise, the payout is made in cash or shares, representing the appreciation in stock value multiplied by the number of units.

These units do not confer ownership rights until exercised and converted into shares or cash.

The number of SAR units is a key parameter in the equity compensation plan impacting employee incentives and retention.

name: Stock Appreciation Rights (SAR) Grant Price
description:
The grant price (also called the exercise price) is the fixed price per unit established at the time of granting Stock Appreciation Rights (SARs).

It is typically the fair market value of the employer’s stock on the grant date.

The SARs’ value is determined by the increase in stock price above this grant price.

When employees exercise their SARs, they receive cash or shares equal to the difference between the current fair market value and the grant price, multiplied by the number of SARs exercised.

The grant price sets the baseline for calculating the financial gain employees realize from their SAR awards.

It is a critical parameter in the SAR plan governing the compensation and incentive structure.

Terms related to the grant price and its adjustment are specified in the employer’s SAR plan and grant agreement.

name: Stock Appreciation Rights (SAR) Exercise Period
description:
The exercise period is the timeframe following the vesting of Stock Appreciation Rights (SARs) during which the employee may exercise those SARs to receive the appreciation value.

It begins immediately after the SARs vest and ends on the expiration date specified by the employer’s SAR plan.

If the employee does not exercise the SARs within this period, the rights typically expire and the employee forfeits the potential payout.

The exercise period dictates the available window for employees to realize gains from SARs before losing the opportunity.

This parameter is critical to employee planning and impacts the timing of compensation received.

Terms regarding exercise period duration and expiration conditions are outlined in the employer’s SAR plan and grant agreement.

The exercise period balances rewarding employees and ensuring timely exercise aligned with organizational policies.

name: Stock Compensation Value No Guarantee
description:
The employee acknowledges that the value of any equity-based compensation or awards is subject to market fluctuations and inherent investment risks.

The employer does not make any guarantees or warranties regarding the future value or market price of equity awards or rights.

No assurance is provided that the awards will retain value or generate financial returns.

This clause protects the employer from liability related to stock price volatility or potential losses experienced by the employee.

It clarifies that equity awards are incentives with uncertain future financial outcomes.

Employees accept these risks as part of their participation in equity compensation programs.

Such disclaimers are standard in equity agreements to set realistic expectations about potential gains or losses.

name: Stock Compensation Tax Compliance
description:
The employee is solely responsible for all tax liabilities arising from the grant, vesting, exercise, purchase, or sale of equity-based compensation awards.

The employer is authorized to withhold necessary tax amounts from any payments made to the employee, in accordance with applicable tax laws and company policies.

All participation in, issuance of, and administration relating to equity-based awards must comply with relevant securities laws, regulations, and the governing plans.

This clause clarifies the division of tax responsibilities and ensures legal compliance in equity compensation.

It protects the employer by affirming their authority to handle tax withholding and the employee’s obligation to fulfill tax liabilities.

Compliance ensures proper reporting, withholding, and remittance of taxes related to equity awards to government authorities.

Employees are encouraged to understand their tax obligations related to their equity compensation.Title: Stock Compensation Tax Compliance

name: Stock Compensation No Shareholder Rights
description:
Equity-based awards do not grant ownership rights such as voting or dividend rights until the underlying shares are actually issued or settled as per plan terms.

Holders of equity awards have no shareholder privileges or participation rights before share issuance.

This provision distinguishes between holding a rights or awards and being a registered shareholder.

It ensures clear governance, reserving shareholder rights exclusively for actual shareholders.

Prevents premature access to corporate governance, dividends, or other shareholder benefits.

Clarifies employee expectations regarding rights associated with their equity compensation awards.

Protects the employer by maintaining control over shareholder rights and avoiding conflicts until shares are issued.

name: Stock Compensation Restrictions
description:
All equity-based awards are subject to transfer, sale, pledge, or other disposition restrictions as defined by the employer’s equity plans, award agreements, and applicable laws.

These restrictions limit the employee's ability to freely transfer or sell equity awards until specified conditions are met.

Restrictions can include vesting requirements, blackout periods, rights of first refusal, and company repurchase rights.

They serve to align employee incentives with long-term company performance and retention.

Compliance with these restrictions is mandatory to preserve the validity of the awards and to meet legal and regulatory requirements.

Employees must understand and adhere to these restrictions to avoid forfeiture or legal consequences.

Restrictions protect company ownership structure and control by preventing premature or unauthorized equity transfers.

name: Stock Compensation Corporate Actions
description:
Equity-based awards' terms, including the number of shares or units granted and exercise or purchase price, may be adjusted following corporate transactions.

Corporate actions triggering adjustments include mergers, stock splits, reorganizations, and similar events.

Adjustments aim to preserve the economic value of the awards despite changes in the company’s capital structure or organization.

The adjustments are governed by the provisions of the employer’s applicable equity compensation plans.

These provisions ensure fair treatment of equity holders during significant corporate events.

They protect employees from dilution or unfair loss of value due to corporate restructuring.

This clause aligns equity compensation with standard market and regulatory practices during corporate actions.Title: Stock Compensation Corporate Actions
Default: false
Description:

Equity award terms, including shares/units granted and exercise/purchase price, may be adjusted due to corporate transactions like mergers, stock splits, or reorganizations.

Adjustments ensure the economic value of equity awards remains consistent despite changes in company structure.

Governed by applicable plans, these provisions protect employees from dilution or value loss during such events.

This clause ensures equity compensation aligns with standard market practices and regulatory requirements during corporate actions.

name: Employment Benefits
description:
The Employee is eligible for a range of benefits as outlined in the employer’s benefit policies and plan documents.

Private Insurance: Participation in private medical and dental insurance plans, with coverage scope, benefits level, and insurer details specified by the employer.

Pension and Retirement Benefits: Eligibility for pension or retirement schemes, including employer contributions and compliance with legal requirements.

Provision of Company Property: Possible provision of equipment or property as per employer policies and acceptable use guidelines.

Life and Disability Insurance: Eligibility for term life, accidental death, short- and long-term disability insurance, and retirement savings plans.

Wellness Program: Access to wellness and employee assistance programs promoting health, well-being, and support for personal or work-related issues.

Professional Development and Relocation: Reimbursement for approved education, training, and relocation expenses subject to prior employer approval and policy terms.

Additional Benefits: May include travel and transportation subsidies, housing allowance, childcare support, meals during working hours, membership fees for professional or social clubs, subject to employer discretion and policies.

Benefits coverage and entitlement may vary based on company policy, plan terms, and legal regulations, providing a comprehensive support system for employees.

name: Private Insurance Participation
description:
The employee is eligible to participate in the employer’s private insurance plans, which typically include medical and dental coverage by default.

Coverage scope, benefit levels, insurer details, and eligibility for dependents are specified in the employer’s benefit policy.

Private insurance benefits provide access to healthcare services beyond statutory or public healthcare provisions.

These plans often cover hospital stays, specialist visits, treatments, dental care, and sometimes vision care.

Participation in private insurance as a benefit supports employee health, well-being, and financial protection against medical costs.

The policy details and options may vary based on employer discretion and negotiated insurer agreements.

Offering such insurance benefits can improve employee satisfaction, retention, and productivity.

name: Employment Insurance Type
description:
Defines the category of private insurance plans provided or offered by the employer to the employee.

Common types include medical, dental, vision, critical illness, accident, and short-term health plans.

Insurance type determines the scope of coverage, benefits, insurers, and applicable policy terms.

Specifies which benefits are available for employees and their dependents under the employer’s insurance program.

The insurance type usually reflects core health-related benefits aimed at supporting employee well-being and financial protection.

Variations in insurance type help tailor benefits packages to employee needs and company resources.

Typically documented in the employer’s benefit policy and plan details for transparency and compliance.

name: Employment Pension and Retirement Benefits
description:
The Employee is eligible to participate in the Employer’s pension or retirement benefit scheme.

Eligibility includes any employer contributions as defined by the terms of the applicable plan.

Participation is subject to compliance with relevant laws and regulations governing pension and retirement plans.

Pension plans can be of different types, including defined benefit and defined contribution plans, tailored to provide retirement income or savings.

Defined benefit plans generally promise a fixed retirement benefit based on salary and years of service.

Defined contribution plans specify contributions, with retirement benefits depending on investment performance.

Participation in these plans provides financial security to employees post-retirement and may include employer matching or other funding mechanisms.

The plan specifics, including benefits, vesting, and contributions, are governed by the plan documents and applicable legal frameworks.

name: Company Property
description:
The employee may be provided with company property or equipment as needed to perform their job functions.

Provision of company property is subject to the employer’s policies and acceptable use guidelines.

Company property can include items such as computers, mobile devices, tools, office supplies, and other equipment necessary for work.

Employees are responsible for the proper use, care, and return of company property in accordance with employer guidelines.

Policies typically specify authorized uses, maintenance responsibilities, and restrictions on personal use of company assets.

Misuse, loss, or damage to company property may result in disciplinary actions or reimbursement obligations.

The clause helps ensure clarity on property provision, usage expectations, and accountability within the employment relationship.

name: Company Property Description
description:
Specifies the type of company property or equipment an employee may be provided with to perform work duties.

Common examples include laptops, mobile devices, office equipment, software licenses, vehicles, tools, and proprietary materials.

The exact description is tailored by the employer based on job role, responsibilities, and operational needs.

Usage of company property is subject to employer policies, including acceptable use guidelines, maintenance, and security.

Employees are generally responsible for proper care, authorized use only, and timely return of provided property.

The description clause clarifies asset provisioning expectations and helps manage accountability.

Clearly outlining property types helps avoid disputes and ensures appropriate resource allocation for employee productivity.

name: Life and Disability Insurance
description:
The employee is eligible to participate in the employer’s life, disability, and retirement plans subject to terms of applicable policies.

Life insurance typically includes term life and accidental death coverage providing financial support to beneficiaries in the event of the employee’s death.

Disability insurance covers short-term and long-term disability scenarios, offering partial income replacement during illness or injury preventing work.

Short-term disability usually provides coverage for temporary disabilities lasting a few months, while long-term extends coverage over extended periods or until retirement.

These insurance plans help maintain employee financial stability during health crises impacting earning capacity.

Participation and benefits are governed by plan documents, eligibility rules, and compliance with laws.

Such insurance offerings are key components of comprehensive employee benefits packages supporting overall well-being and security.

name: Life and Disability Insurance Details
description:
Details the specific types of life and disability insurance coverage included in the employer's benefits.

Common components include:

Term life insurance providing financial protection in case of employee death.

Accidental death coverage offering benefits in case of fatal accidents.

Short-term disability insurance that replaces a portion of income during temporary disability (often up to a few months).

Long-term disability insurance that provides income replacement for extended or permanent disabilities.

Retirement savings plans such as 401(k), RRSP, or pension schemes.

These insurance details outline the scope and nature of coverage available to the employee, subject to plan terms.

Coverage protects the employee and their beneficiaries against financial hardship arising from death, accident, or disability.

The insurance types and terms are defined under applicable policies, often including eligibility criteria, benefit limits, and exclusions.

This parameter clarifies the range of protections afforded and the employee's access to these key benefits.

name: Wellness Program
description:
Provides employee access to wellness benefits and Employee Assistance Programs (EAP) focused on supporting health and well-being.

Programs are designed to help employees manage personal or work-related challenges holistically, including physical, mental, and emotional health.

Typical components include fitness initiatives, mental health counseling, stress management resources, health screenings, and nutritional support.

EAPs often provide confidential counseling services for personal, family, or workplace issues.

Wellness programs aim to improve employee engagement, productivity, and reduce absenteeism by fostering healthier lifestyles.

Participation and specific benefits are subject to the terms and conditions of the employer’s wellness program policies.

Offering wellness programs contributes to a positive workplace culture and supports overall employee satisfaction and retention.

name: Professional Development
description:
The employer may reimburse the employee for approved education and training expenses, including tuition, course fees, seminars, certifications, and potentially relocation costs.

Reimbursements are subject to the terms of the employer’s professional development policy and require prior written approval from the employer.

Supports employee skill enhancement, career growth, and alignment with organizational goals.

Covers a broad range of development activities including formal courses, workshops, certifications, and conferences.

Encourages continuous learning and capability building, fostering a motivated and competent workforce.

Helps employees stay current with industry trends, regulatory requirements, and evolving job functions.

Prior approval ensures alignment with budget, relevance, and organizational strategy in professional development investments.

name: Additional Benefits
description:
The employee may receive additional benefits at the employer’s discretion and according to company policy.

These benefits supplement core compensation and statutory benefits, enhancing overall employee satisfaction.

Typical additional benefits include travel and transportation subsidies to offset commuting costs.

Housing allowances help with accommodation expenses for eligible employees.

Childcare support may include subsidies or access to childcare services.

Complimentary or subsidized meals during working hours are often provided as wellness and convenience benefits.

Membership fees for professional or social clubs support networking, professional growth, and social engagement.

Additional benefits can vary widely based on employer strategy, budget, and workforce needs, and are subject to change without guarantee.

name: Additional Benefits Details
description:
Specifies the range of additional benefits that an employee may receive at the employer's discretion under company policy.

Typical benefits include travel subsidies or commuter reimbursements to ease commuting costs.

Housing allowances assist employees with accommodation expenses, especially in high-cost areas or relocations.

Childcare support may come as subsidies or access to childcare services, supporting employees with family care responsibilities.

Provision of meals or snacks during working hours is a common wellness-focused benefit.

Payment or reimbursement of membership fees for professional or social clubs, fostering networking and community engagement.

Additional benefits are variable, reflecting company priorities, employee needs, and budget considerations.

Such benefits enhance employee satisfaction, loyalty, and work-life balance beyond basic compensation.

name: Expense Reimbursement
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employee is entitled to reimbursement for reasonable and properly incurred expenses related to their job duties.

true: The Employer will reimburse the Employee for all reasonable expenses directly connected to their work, provided the expenses comply with the Employer’s current expense policy and are pre-approved in writing by the Employee’s Appropriate Manager, unless the policy states otherwise. To claim reimbursement, the Employee must submit a completed expense report along with original receipts or acceptable proof of payment within a specified number of days after incurring the expense. The Employer may withhold reimbursement if the expenses do not meet policy requirements or lack proper documentation. Any falsification or misuse of the expense process may lead to disciplinary action, including termination.

false: The related provisions will not be included in the employment agreement.

name: Work Hours Type
description:
parameter specifies the type of working hours arrangement applicable to the Employee:

If set to fixed: The Employee’s normal working hours are specified as fixed start and end times on designated working days each week, including a defined lunch break. This schedule is consistent and applies regularly as set by the Employer.

If set to flexible: The Employee is expected to work a specified number of days and total hours per week. The exact working times and days are determined and may be reasonably adjusted by the Employer to meet operational needs.

In both cases, the Employee may be required to work additional hours as reasonably necessary to fulfill their duties, subject to applicable laws. The Employee also agrees to be flexible in working hours when the nature of the role demands it, complying with any reasonable Employer requests.

name: Employment Work Week Days
description:
This parameter specifies the regular working days during which the Employee is expected to perform their duties.

It defines the standard days of the week that constitute the Employee’s normal work schedule, clarifying which days are considered the Employee’s official working days.

This parameter is fundamental for setting expectations regarding attendance, scheduling, payroll calculation, and leave management.

It helps align the Employee’s work pattern with the Company’s operational requirements and industry norms, ensuring clear communication of working hours and days.

Typically, this parameter excludes weekends and public holidays unless the role requires non-standard shifts or weekend work.

Properly defining work week days supports compliance with labor laws and helps manage work-life balance by setting boundaries for work availability.

Default: A common default value for this parameter is Monday through Friday, reflecting the standard full-time workweek in many countries and industries.

name: Work Week Start Day
description: Specifies the first day of the Employee’s normal working week when the work hours are fixed. This parameter defines the starting weekday from which the Employee’s regular work schedule begins each week.

name: Work Week End Day
description: Specifies the last day of the Employee’s normal working week when the work hours are fixed. This parameter defines the ending weekday of the Employee’s regular work schedule each week.

name: Lunch Break Duration
description:
Specifies the duration of the Employee’s lunch break during their normal fixed working day. This duration defines the standard amount of unpaid time allocated for the Employee’s lunch or meal break within the daily working hours.

Format: Duration expressed in a typical time format such as hours and/or minutes (e.g., "30 minutes", "1 hour", "00:30"). The format should be consistent with the Employer’s internal policy or system requirements.

name: Flexible Work Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the total number of working hours the Employee is expected to complete within a specified period under a flexible work arrangement.

It defines the overall workload commitment without prescribing fixed start and end times, allowing the Employee to organize their workday with flexibility while ensuring the total required hours are met.

This parameter supports varying flexible work models such as flextime, compressed workweeks, or remote work, promoting work-life balance and accommodating personal and business needs.

The flexibility granted by this parameter can enhance employee satisfaction and productivity, while the clear hour requirement maintains accountability and operational effectiveness.

It serves as a critical component in balancing Employer control with Employee autonomy over scheduling.

Default: A typical default value for this parameter is 40 hours, reflecting the standard full-time workweek expectation in many countries and industries.

name: Flexible Work Duration Unit
description:
This parameter defines the unit of time used to measure the total flexible working hours specified in the employment_flexible_work_duration parameter.

This unit provides the context for how the total working hours are calculated and interpreted, such as hours per day, per week, or per month, ensuring clarity in work hour expectations.

It enables precise specification of flexible working arrangements by setting a clear timeframe over which the required work hours must be completed.

This parameter is crucial for aligning work schedules, payroll calculations, and compliance with employment laws related to working time.

Common units accommodate various organizational structures, allowing employers to tailor work periods to operational and employee needs.

Default: A typical default value for this parameter is per week, reflecting standard workweek measurement conventions and facilitating consistent application of flexible work policies.

name: Additional Work Outside Normal Hours
description:
parameter indicates whether the Employee may be required to work reasonable additional hours beyond their normal working schedule.

true: The Employee agrees to work additional hours as reasonably needed for the proper performance of their duties. These extra hours are generally unpaid unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Employer and the Employee or required by applicable law. The Employer will adhere to all relevant laws regarding working hours, rest periods, and overtime.

false: The paragraph shall not be included in the agreement.

name: Annual Leave
description: This parameter determines whether the detailed annual leave provisions apply to the Employee’s contract. When enabled (true), the Employee’s annual leave entitlements and related rules are included in the Employment Agreement. If it is false, these provisions will not be included in the Agreement and will instead be governed by Company policy and applicable law.

name: Paid Leave Entitlement Type
description:
The employment_leave_days parameter specifies the scope of paid leave entitlement granted to the Employee.

When set to ‘unlimited’, the Employee shall be entitled to unlimited paid leave subject to the needs of the Employer and the Employee’s duty to effectively fulfill their responsibilities. Leave under this provision must be requested and approved in advance according to the Employer’s policies to ensure proper coverage and operational continuity. This does not affect the Employer’s right to require the Employee’s presence as reasonably necessary. All leave granted shall align with applicable laws and shall not diminish the Employee’s statutory entitlements.

When set to ‘limited’, the Employee shall be entitled to a fixed number of paid leave days during each leave year, specified as {{ employment_annual_leave_days }}.

This parameter allows flexibility for Employers to offer either an unlimited leave policy conditional on operational needs or a specific fixed annual leave entitlement to Employees.

name: Public Holidays Inclusion in Annual Leave
description:
Defines how public holidays are treated in relation to the Employee’s annual paid holiday entitlement within the employment agreement or handbook.

Value: 'excluded'
- The Employee’s stated annual holiday entitlement (e.g., 20 days) excludes public holidays observed in the jurisdiction specified by employment_public_holiday_region.
- Public holidays are granted in addition to the annual leave days. Thus, public holidays do not reduce the Employee’s annual leave balance.
- Example: If the Employee is entitled to 20 days’ annual leave and there are 8 public holidays in the year, the Employee effectively receives 28 days off (20 annual leave days + 8 public holidays).
- If a public holiday falls during a period when the Employee is already on annual leave (and it would normally be a working day), the public holiday day is not counted against the annual leave. The Employee’s leave duration is extended accordingly or an additional day off is granted.
- This treatment ensures the Employee is not “charged” annual leave for a public holiday occurring during their leave.

Value: 'included'
- The Employee’s stated annual holiday entitlement (e.g., 25 days) includes the usual public holidays observed in the jurisdiction specified by employment_public_holiday_region.
- Public holidays count within the annual leave days; therefore, if the Employee takes leave over public holidays, those public holidays are counted against their total leave entitlement.
- Example: An Employee with 25 days’ annual leave including public holidays effectively has fewer days of discretionary leave than if public holidays were excluded.
- If the Employee is required to work on a public holiday, the Employer may compensate the Employee either by granting a day off in lieu or by providing additional pay, subject to applicable laws and company policies.
- This approach bundles statutory holidays within the overall leave entitlement for simplicity and consistency with certain local employment practices.

display.label: Public Holidays Inclusion in Annual Leave

name: Number of Annual Leave Days
description:
This parameter specifies the total number of paid annual leave days that an employee is entitled to during each annual leave year. This represents the core annual leave allowance granted to the employee in accordance with the Employer’s annual leave policy or statutory requirements. The parameter’s value must comply with statutory minimums for annual leave applicable to the employment jurisdiction but may be set higher as a contractual benefit.

The treatment of public holidays (whether included or excluded) significantly affects the employee’s total paid time off during the year. Employers typically define this clearly in their policies to avoid ambiguity.

When Public Holidays Are Excluded:

The employee receives the specified number of paid annual leave days in addition to the usual public holidays observed in the relevant region.

Public holidays are not deducted from or counted within this annual leave allowance; rather, they are granted separately as paid days off.

This approach increases the total number of paid leave days during the year since public holidays are additional to the base annual leave days.
Example: If the parameter is set to 20 days and the region observes 8 public holidays, the employee effectively has 28 paid days off during the year.

When Public Holidays Are Included:

The employee’s total paid leave entitlement, as specified by the parameter, includes the usual public holidays observed in the relevant region, meaning public holidays count toward the annual leave total.

If the employee is required to work on a public holiday, the Employer may provide a substitute day off (“day off in lieu”) or additional payment, in compliance with applicable laws or contractual terms.

Under this approach, annual leave days and public holidays combine to form a single entitlement pool, resulting in fewer discretionary annual leave days separate from public holidays.

name: Seniority-Based Additional Leave Entitlement
description:
This parameter controls whether the Employment Agreement includes a provision granting the Employee additional paid annual leave days based on completed years of continuous service with the Employer, over and above the base annual leave entitlement.

When set to TRUE (Include Seniority Leave Adjustment):

The Employee receives extra paid annual leave days calculated according to their seniority.

For each full year of continuous service beyond a defined threshold, the Employee is granted an additional set number of annual leave days.

There is a maximum cap on the total additional annual leave days the Employee can accrue in each annual leave year.

Only full years completed count toward this entitlement; partial years (e.g., if employment starts during a leave year) are excluded from calculation unless the Employer agrees otherwise in writing.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Seniority Leave Adjustment):

The Employment Agreement does not include a provision for additional annual leave days based on seniority.

The Employee’s annual leave entitlement is limited to the base annual leave days defined elsewhere in the Agreement, without any increase linked to length of continuous service.

Purpose and Importance:

Rewards Loyalty: Encourages and rewards long-term service by enhancing annual leave benefits in recognition of employee seniority.

Clear Calculation Framework: Establishes a straightforward formula for additional annual leave entitlement, capped to maintain fairness and manage costs.

Contractual Certainty: Provides a clear contractual basis for additional leave to prevent disputes or misunderstandings related to seniority entitlements.

Flexibility: Allows the Employer discretion to decide if partial years count toward seniority, supporting practical workforce management.

name: Seniority Threshold for Additional Leave Days
description:
This parameter defines the minimum number of completed full years of continuous service with the Employer that an Employee must reach before becoming eligible for additional paid annual leave days based on seniority. It establishes a service threshold that acts as the starting point for calculating extra annual leave entitlement awarded for long service.

Employees do not receive additional annual leave days for any years of service up to and including this threshold. Additional leave days accrue only for full years of service beyond this number.

This threshold provides a clear qualification period after which seniority benefits apply, helping the Employer manage leave benefits cost-effectively while appropriately rewarding employee loyalty.

Contextual Use: This threshold works alongside other parameters such as the number of additional annual leave days granted per year beyond the threshold and the maximum cap on additional leave days. It forms part of a progressive annual leave benefit designed to encourage retention and recognize long-term service.

Example: If the seniority threshold is set at 3 years, an Employee who has completed 5 full years of service is entitled to additional annual leave days for 2 years only (years 4 and 5), not for the first 3 years. An Employee with less than or exactly 3 years of service is not entitled to any additional seniority-based leave unless the Employer agrees otherwise in writing.

Special Note on Partial Year Service: Partial years within a holiday year at the start of employment are typically excluded from the seniority calculation unless explicitly agreed otherwise to ensure additional leave is granted solely for fully completed years beyond the threshold.

display.label: Seniority Threshold for Additional Leave Days

name: Additional Leave Days Per Year of Service
description:
This parameter specifies the number of additional paid annual leave days an Employee earns for each full year of continuous service completed beyond a defined minimum service threshold with the Employer. It forms part of a seniority-based leave adjustment scheme that rewards employee loyalty and long service.

Once the Employee surpasses the specified seniority threshold, they begin to accrue extra annual leave days each year at the rate indicated by this parameter. The additional days are granted per full year of service completed beyond the threshold and are added to the Employee’s base annual leave entitlement.

Purpose and Effect: This encourages long-term employment by increasing paid time off in recognition of ongoing commitment and experience.

Interaction with Other Parameters:

The total additional annual leave days an Employee can accrue is typically capped by a maximum limit (e.g., maximum total additional entitlement).

The calculation excludes any partial first year if the Employee starts partway through an annual leave year, unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Employer.

This parameter works alongside the base annual leave entitlement parameter to determine the Employee’s total annual leave entitlement.

Practical Example: If this parameter is set to 1 day per year and the seniority threshold is 3 years, an Employee with 5 full years of service would receive 2 additional annual leave days each year on top of their base entitlement, subject to any maximum cap.

display.label: Additional Leave Days Per Year of Service

name: Maximum Seniority-Based Additional Leave Days
description:
This parameter sets the maximum limit on the number of additional paid annual leave days an Employee can receive annually as an adjustment for years of continuous service beyond a defined threshold.

Purpose and Effect: This parameter caps the total number of additional annual leave days granted based on length of service, ensuring that while employee loyalty and tenure are rewarded, the extra leave does not become excessive or unmanageable for the Employer.

name: Leave Year Start Date
description:
This parameter specifies the exact calendar date on which the Employer’s official annual leave year begins. This date marks the commencement of the annual leave entitlement cycle for the Employee.

Purpose and Effect:

Defines the start of the annual leave period during which leave entitlements accrue, are tracked, and may be used by the Employee.

Establishes the timeframe against which all leave accruals, carryovers, and usage are measured.

Is important for determining the pro-rata annual leave entitlement when employment starts or ends partway through the annual leave year.

This parameter enables both the Employer and Employee to clearly understand the boundaries of the annual leave period for administrative purposes and legal compliance.

name: Leave Year End Date
description:
This parameter specifies the final calendar date on which the Employer’s designated annual leave year ends. This date marks the conclusion of the annual period used for calculating, tracking, and administering the Employee’s annual leave entitlement and usage.

Purpose and Effect:

Defines the endpoint of the Employer’s annual leave year, establishing the standard cycle for leave accrual, entitlement, and reconciliation.

Along with the corresponding annual leave year start date, it creates a fixed period (typically 12 months) that governs when annual leave is earned and when unused leave may expire or be carried forward.

Establishes the temporal boundary for pro-rating annual leave entitlement when an Employee’s start or termination date falls within an annual leave year.

This parameter helps the Employer and Employee clearly identify the boundaries of the annual leave period for administrative accuracy and legal compliance.

name: Leave Advanced Notice
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employee is required to provide advance written notice to the Employer before taking any annual leave.

When set to true, the Employee must submit a formal written request specifying the proposed leave dates within a minimum notice period (defined elsewhere, often as a number of weeks). The Employer’s written approval of the requested dates must be obtained prior to the Employee taking leave. This requirement helps coordinate leave planning and ensures business operations are not disrupted.

If set to false, no formal advance written notice or approval is required, allowing for more flexible and informal annual leave arrangements.

name: Take Leave - Advance Notice Period
description:
This parameter specifies the minimum number of weeks’ written notice that the Employee must provide to the Employer when requesting to take annual leave. The Employee is required to submit this notice in writing at least the specified number of weeks before the intended leave dates. The proposed annual leave dates are subject to approval and must be confirmed in writing by the designated approving authority.

Purpose and Effect:

Ensures that Employees submit their annual leave requests sufficiently in advance, allowing the Employer ample time to plan and manage workforce scheduling and operations effectively.

Facilitates orderly and fair management of leave requests, helping to avoid conflicts or staffing shortages during critical business periods.

Encourages open communication and transparency between the Employee and Employer regarding planned absences.

name: Maximum Consecutive Leave Days
description:
This parameter sets a limit on the number of consecutive annual leave days an Employee may take without obtaining prior written consent from an authorized approver within the Employer’s organization. It controls the length of continuous annual leave an Employee may take at one time, allowing the Employer to manage workforce availability and maintain business continuity. This helps prevent extended absences that could disrupt operations or unduly burden other staff.

By requiring prior written consent for leave periods exceeding this limit, the Employer can evaluate and approve extended annual leave requests based on operational needs and fairness.

Context within the Employment Clause: Employees may take annual leave up to the maximum consecutive days freely, subject to usual notice and approval processes. For any leave period exceeding this maximum, the Employee must obtain explicit prior written approval from the designated authority.

name: Consecutive Leave Approval Authority
description:
This parameter specifies the job title, role, or designated position within the Employer’s organization that has the authority to approve requests for taking a number of consecutive annual leave days exceeding the standard permitted limit.

Typical Examples: Line Manager, Department Head, Human Resources Manager, Senior Manager, Director.

name: Maximum Consecutive Leave Days Threshold
description:
This parameter specifies the maximum number of consecutive paid annual leave days an Employee is permitted to take at any one time without first obtaining prior written approval from the designated approver. It limits the length of continuous annual leave to ensure operational continuity and maintain adequate staffing levels within the organization. This encourages Employees to spread their leave over the year rather than taking extended uninterrupted absences, which could disrupt workflow or team productivity.

Context within the Clause: Employees may take annual leave up to the specified maximum number of consecutive days freely, subject to the normal notice and approval procedures. For any leave period exceeding this maximum, the Employee must seek and obtain explicit prior written consent from the designated approving authority.

Practical Implications:

Facilitates better planning and coordination of workloads, preventing overlapping long-term absences.

Reduces potential operational risks arising from prolonged employee absence.

Provides a controlled and transparent process for authorizing extended leave periods.

name: Employer’s Right to Direct Leave Timing
description:
This parameter specifies whether the Employer has the contractual right to require the Employee to take annual leave on specific designated days, rather than relying solely on the Employee’s request for leave. This provision empowers the Employer to mandate that the Employee uses their annual leave entitlement during particular periods, often to align with business needs, such as seasonal quiet periods, company shutdowns, or operational requirements.

It allows the Employer to proactively manage holiday scheduling to maintain workforce planning and prevent understaffing during critical times.

If this parameter is set to true, the Employment Agreement will include a clause affirming the Employer’s right to require the Employee to take annual leave on designated days.

If set to false, no such clause will be included, meaning the Employee retains full discretion to choose when to take leave, subject to normal approval processes.

display.label: Employer's Right to Direct Leave Timing

name: Transfer of Untaken Leave
description:
This parameter controls the handling of unused annual leave entitlements at the end of the annual leave year. It is an enumerated parameter with four possible values defining the rules and limitations related to carrying over or forfeiting unused leave:

‘forfeit’: Any accrued annual leave not taken within the annual leave year it was earned will automatically lapse and be forfeited, except where overridden by applicable law or by explicit written agreement from the Employer. This “use it or lose it” approach encourages timely leave utilization and helps Employers manage liabilities from unused leave.

‘carryover-limited’: Employees may carry forward unused annual leave up to a specified maximum ({{ employment_holiday_max_carryover }} days). Leave beyond this limit is forfeited unless the Employer agrees otherwise in writing. This policy balances flexibility with limits on excessive leave accrual.

‘carryover-limited-time-bar’: Similar to ‘carryover-limited’ but with an additional time restriction. Carried-over leave must be used within a defined period ({{ employment_carryover_taking_period }}) following the new annual leave year, or it is forfeited. This provision promotes prompt use of carried-over leave and minimizes long-term accrual.

‘carryover-unlimited’: Employees may carry forward unlimited unused annual leave days to the subsequent annual leave year without any cap. Leave must be scheduled and taken at a mutually agreed time, providing maximum flexibility while meeting operational requirements.

Default Setting: ‘carryover-limited’ is a common default that balances fair employee leave usage with the Employer’s need to control leave liability and operational planning.

name: Leave Maximum Carryover
description:
This parameter specifies the maximum number of unused paid annual leave days that an Employee is permitted to carry forward from one annual leave year into the next.

Purpose and Effect: This parameter sets a cap on the amount of accrued but unused annual leave entitlement that can be preserved and utilized beyond the current annual leave year.

Any unused annual leave entitlement exceeding this maximum carryover limit will be forfeited, meaning the Employee loses the right to take or be compensated for such excess leave unless there is an explicit written agreement to the contrary.

Context within the Clause: Employees typically accrue paid annual leave each year under their contract or statutory entitlements. To encourage periodic leave-taking and manage leave liability, Employers often impose a restriction on the amount of unused leave that can be carried over to the following year.

The maximum carryover limit may be expressed as a fixed number of days (e.g., 5 or 10 days) or as zero, meaning no carryover is allowed unless subject to prior agreement.

Example: If the parameter is set to 5 days, an Employee may carry forward at most 5 unused annual leave days from the current year to the next. Any additional unused days beyond 5 will be forfeited unless the Employer provides explicit written consent.

Default: A common default for this parameter is 5 days, which balances employee flexibility with the Employer’s need to control leave liabilities and operational planning.

name: Leave Carryover Taking Period
description:
This parameter defines the maximum allowable time period within which an Employee must use any unused annual leave entitlement carried forward from a previous annual leave year.

It sets a clear deadline from the start of the new leave year by which carried-over leave must be taken, ensuring leave is used in a timely manner and does not accumulate indefinitely.

By imposing this time limit, the Employer can effectively manage leave liabilities and encourage Employees to utilize their leave to support wellbeing and work-life balance.

This measure also helps prevent operational disruptions caused by the accumulation of excessive unused leave, which can impact staffing and productivity.

The parameter provides clarity and certainty for both the Employer and Employee regarding the timeframe for using carried-over annual leave, reducing potential disputes over entitlement and expiry.

Typically, this period ranges from several months to one or two years, depending on company policy and applicable statutory requirements.

Default: A common default value for this parameter is 12 months (1 year) from the start of the new leave year, balancing flexibility for Employees with the Employer’s need for effective leave management.

name: Exceptions to Leave Carryover Limits
description:
This parameter determines whether an Employee is permitted to carry forward unused annual leave entitlement beyond the usual maximum carryover limit in exceptional circumstances—specifically, if the Employee was unable to take their annual leave due to statutory family-related leave (such as maternity, paternity, or adoption leave).

If set to true, the Employee may exceed the normal carryover cap on unused annual leave days when prevented from taking leave due to statutory family-related leave during the relevant leave year.

If set to false, this provision will not appear in the Employment Agreement and the handling of unused leave will default to company policy or applicable law.

name: Payment for Untaken Leaves
description:
This parameter governs the policy on payment for accrued but untaken annual leave. It is an enumerated parameter with four possible values that define when and if Employees are compensated monetarily for unused leave.

no-payment: No payment is made for any untaken annual leave during the course of employment or upon its termination, except where required by applicable law. This policy typically encourages Employees to use their holiday entitlement during employment and avoids financial liabilities for unused leave.

pay-accrued: Annual leave accrues progressively throughout the employment and any untaken accrued leave is compensated as part of the Employee’s remuneration. Payment can be made during regular pay periods or as a lump sum upon termination. This ensures that Employees are financially compensated for leave earned but not yet taken.

pay-request: The Employer may, at its sole discretion and subject to operational requirements, compensate the Employee for accrued but untaken leave during the term of employment if the Employee submits a written request. This policy offers flexibility and control to the Employer while providing Employees the opportunity to monetize unused leave with approval.

payment-termination: Upon termination of employment, the Employee is entitled to payment in lieu of any accrued but untaken leave, calculated proportionally to the length of service completed during the leave year and accounting for any excessive leave already taken. This ensures fair compensation for leave earned but unused at the end of employment.

Default: A commonly used default is payment-termination, ensuring Employees receive fair monetary compensation for accrued but unused leave upon ending employment, aligning with many statutory requirements.

name: Deduction for Unaccrued Leave Taken
description:
This parameter determines whether the Employer has the right to deduct from the Employee’s final payments an amount equivalent to the pay for any annual leave days taken in excess of the Employee’s accrued entitlement at the end of their employment.

True: This clause will be included in the Employee’s contract, specifying that if the Employee takes more annual leave than they have accrued by the time their employment ends, the Employer can recover the excess pay by deducting it from amounts owed to the Employee, such as final salary or other termination payments.

False: This clause will be excluded from the contract, and no explicit right to make such deductions for excess annual leave pay will be granted to the Employer.

Clause Summary (when included):

The Employer may recover pay for any annual leave taken in advance (beyond accrued entitlement) by deducting the corresponding amount from sums payable to the Employee upon termination.

This protects the Employer from loss where the Employee’s leave balance is negative upon leaving.

The deduction amount is based on the Employee’s pay rate for each excess annual leave day.

name: Sickness Absence
description:
It determines whether the full sickness absence clause is included in the employment contract or policy document.

If true: the complete sickness absence clause, including requirements for absence notification, self-certification, doctor’s certificates, and medical examination consent, will be included in the employee’s terms.

If false: the entire sickness absence clause is excluded from the contract or policy document, meaning no formal sickness absence reporting or certification requirements are imposed within the employee’s terms.

Clause Summary (if included):
Employee must notify the manager at the start of any absence and complete relevant absence certification on return.
Doctor’s certificates are required for absences exceeding a specified threshold of consecutive days.
Employee consents to medical examinations requested by the Employer, with reports shared for absence management purposes.

name: Doctor’s Certificate Requirement Threshold
description:
It specifies the minimum number of consecutive days of sickness or injury absence after which the Employee is required to obtain and submit a doctor's certificate to the Employer.

Purpose and Effect:
- This parameter sets the threshold duration for when formal medical evidence is needed to justify an absence due to sickness or injury.
- For absences shorter than this number of days, the Employee can typically self-certify their absence via a self-certification form on return to work.
- For absences lasting this number of days or more consecutively, a valid doctor's certificate stating the reason for absence must be obtained by the Employee (usually at their own cost) and supplied promptly to the Appropriate Manager.
- If the absence continues beyond the period covered by the original certificate, further certificates must be obtained accordingly.

Context within the Clause: The requirement for a doctor's certificate supports the Employer's need to verify and document sickness absences, helping manage attendance and operational planning.

Operational Importance:
Helps prevent abuse of sick leave by ensuring medical validation beyond a certain duration.
Enables consistent application of sickness absence verification procedures.
Supports compliance with local laws and company policies regarding sickness certification.

Typical Values: Common thresholds range from 3 to 7 consecutive days depending on jurisdiction and company policy.

name: Consent to Medical Examination and Disclosure
description:
It determines whether the employment contract or policy includes a clause requiring the Employee to consent to a medical examination arranged and paid for by the Employer when requested.

Purpose and Effect:
- If true: the clause obligates the Employee to undergo a medical examination by a doctor nominated and paid for by the Employer, upon the Employer’s reasonable request, to assess the Employee’s health or fitness for work.

The Employee also agrees that the medical report from this examination can be disclosed to the Employer and discussed with the examining doctor, facilitating transparent management of health-related employment decisions.

If false: this medical examination clause is omitted from the employment terms, and there is no contractual obligation for the Employee to undergo such an examination at the Employer’s request.

display.label: Consent to Medical Examination and Disclosure

name: Statutory and Discretionary Sick Pay
description:
It controls whether the employment contract or policy includes a clause about the Employee's entitlement to sick pay during illness or injury absence.

If true: the clause is included and states that the Employee is entitled to receive any statutory sick pay or equivalent benefits as required by applicable law. Additionally, the Employer may provide extra discretionary sick pay or benefits according to company policies. Payment entitlement is conditional on the Employee complying with notification and sickness evidence requirements.

If false: this sick pay clause is omitted from the contract or policy document.

This parameter enables employers to toggle inclusion of standard sick pay provisions, which ensure employees receive legally mandated sick pay while allowing employers discretion to offer enhanced benefits and requiring proper absence reporting.

name: Employment Termination Notice Type
description:
This parameter specifies the structure and nature of the termination notice period required for ending the Employee's contract, varying by the type of employment appointment. It defines how and when either party—the Employer or the Employee—may terminate the employment agreement, including the required notice, conditions, and any scaling based on tenure.

Notice Types and Effects:

at-will: Available for appointment types: indefinite, fixed-term-with-notice, and initial-fixed-then-notice. This type permits either party to terminate the Agreement at any time, with or without cause, and with or without providing notice, unless otherwise restricted by applicable law or contract terms. It offers the greatest flexibility for termination. While widely accepted in the many US states, this type is generally not recognized or enforceable in most other jurisdictions with stronger employee protections where minimum notice or cause is required.

fixed-notice: This requires a specified minimum notice period to be given in writing before termination. Widely required in most jurisdictions including Europe, Canada, Australia, and many parts of Asia and the Middle East. Statutory minimum notice periods exist and contracts must comply or extend these requirements. Pay in lieu of notice is often allowed when notice is not served.

scaling-notice: Designed to reflect increasing tenure, this type applies to indefinite and initial-fixed-then-notice after the initial fixed term. Its common in jurisdictions with seniority-based protections (e.g., Germany, France, Canada, Australia). Notice periods increase with length of service, scaling the notice period based on continuous years of employment. Contracts must align with legally mandated increments and maximum limits.

Legal Jurisdiction Considerations: The enforceability and applicability of these termination notice types depend heavily on the governing law where the employment is situated. Employers must clearly specify the governing jurisdiction in the contract and ensure the chosen value complies with mandatory local labor laws. Legal review is recommended to validate the enforceability of termination provisions and avoid disputes.

name: Fixed-Length Notice Period Duration
description:
Specifies the minimum length of the prior written notice period, typically expressed in calendar months, that either the Employer or the Employee must provide to lawfully terminate the employment agreement when the termination notice type is set to fixed-notice. This period ensures that both parties have reasonable time to prepare for the end of the employment relationship, allowing for an orderly transition.

Default: No universal default; should be set according to the Employer’s policy and comply with the minimum statutory requirements in the applicable jurisdiction.

Jurisdictional Note: The specified notice period must meet or exceed mandatory legal minimums in the country or region governing the contract. Failure to comply with local labor laws may render the notice period unenforceable or lead to automatic extensions. Employers should ensure this parameter is aligned with statutory notice obligations to avoid disputes.

name: Threshold for Scaled Notice Period
description:
This parameter specifies the minimum number of continuous years of employment that serve as a threshold before incremental increases in the notice period apply under a scaling notice termination arrangement. If an Employee’s continuous service is less than this threshold, a base notice period applies.
