For service beyond this threshold, the required notice period increases incrementally per completed year of employment, up to a defined maximum.

This parameter helps determine when notice periods start scaling based on employee tenure, ensuring fair and graduated notice requirements for longer-serving employees.
The threshold must comply with applicable local labor laws, which may specify minimum notice periods and how notice periods scale with length of service. Employers should ensure this parameter aligns with statutory or contractual obligations to maintain enforceability.

name: Base Notice Period (Before Scaling)
description:
Specifies the base minimum length of the prior written notice period, typically expressed in calendar months, required from either the Employer or the Employee to terminate the employment contract under a scaling notice arrangement. This base notice period applies when the Employee’s continuous service is below the threshold for incremental increases in notice duration.
The parameter ensures that employees with shorter tenure receive at least this minimum notice before termination, establishing a fair and consistent foundation for notice periods that may increase with length of service.
The base notice period must meet or exceed mandatory statutory minimums in the contract’s governing jurisdiction. Employers should ensure this value aligns with local legal requirements to maintain enforceability of termination notices.

name: Notice Period Increment Based on Length of Service
description:
This parameter specifies the incremental increase in the required notice period for termination that applies for each completed duration unit of continuous employment beyond a defined threshold.

Notice Period Increment Based on Length of Service: Upon completion of a specified minimum period of continuous employment with the Employer, the required notice period shall be extended by a set duration for each additional full year of service.

Scaling Mechanism: This increment is added progressively to the base or minimum notice period, reflecting longer service with a correspondingly longer notice requirement.

Limits and Caps: While the notice period increases by this defined duration annually, the total notice period cannot exceed a predetermined maximum, ensuring a reasonable cap on notice length.

Measurement of Duration: The parameter's value represents a time unit (such as days, weeks, or months) by which the notice period is extended per additional year of service.

Purpose and Importance:
Fairness and Recognition: Recognizes and rewards employee loyalty and long service by requiring longer notice periods as tenure increases.
Legal and Contractual Clarity: Provides a clear, formulaic approach to calculating notice periods that scale with length of employment, reducing ambiguity and potential disputes.
Operational Planning: Helps both Employer and Employee anticipate termination notice requirements based on seniority, facilitating better workforce management and transition planning.

Considerations:
The exact unit of duration (days, weeks, months) should align with other notice period parameters or contractual standards.
This parameter works together with the base notice period, scaling threshold, and maximum notice period settings to determine final notice obligations.

name: Notice Period Ceiling for Service-Based Scaling
description:
This parameter defines the maximum allowable notice period duration that can be required from either party upon termination of employment when a scaling notice period scheme is applied.

Context and Function: In contracts where the required notice period increases incrementally based on the Employee’s length of continuous service beyond a certain threshold, this parameter sets a cap on how long that notice period can grow. Specifically:

The notice period starts from a base length. For each full year of continuous employment beyond the defined threshold, the notice period increases by a fixed increment.

However, the total notice period cannot exceed the maximum duration specified by this parameter, regardless of how many years of service have been completed.

Purpose and Importance:
Limits Notice Period Growth: Prevents the notice period from becoming unreasonably long as seniority increases.

Provides Certainty: Both Employer and Employee have a clear maximum bound on their notice obligations.

Balances Flexibility and Fairness: Allows notice periods to scale with length of service while maintaining practical limits.

Supports Legal Compliance: Ensures notice requirements remain within enforceable and customary bounds according to applicable law or company policy.

Additional Considerations:
The value should be set thoughtfully to balance employee protection and employer operational flexibility.
Typical units for this parameter are days, weeks, or months depending on jurisdiction and contract language.
Used in conjunction with related parameters defining the base notice, threshold and increment duration.

name: Immediate Termination for Just Cause
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employer has the right to terminate the Employee’s employment immediately, without notice or payment in lieu of notice, when there is just cause. Just cause typically includes serious reasons such as Serious Misconduct, Gross Negligence, Material Breach of the employment agreement, dishonesty, fraud, or any other conduct rendering continued employment untenable under applicable law.

The definition and scope of just cause for immediate termination vary by jurisdiction. Some laws require procedural fairness, documented evidence, or specific grounds to lawfully terminate without notice. Employers should ensure that this parameter and corresponding policies comply with local labor laws to avoid wrongful dismissal claims.

True: The employer may terminate the employment immediately if justified by serious reasons such as gross misconduct, serious breach of contract, or other conduct that fundamentally undermines the employment relationship. No advance notice or severance is required in these cases.

False: The agreement does not include a just cause termination clause.

name: Garden Leave
description:
A boolean flag that indicates whether the Employer has the right to place the Employee on garden leave during the notice period after either party gives notice to terminate the employment. When enabled (true), the Employer may require the Employee to refrain from attending the workplace and/or performing some or all of their usual duties during part or all of the notice period, while continuing to pay salary and benefits.

During garden leave, the Employee remains employed and must typically remain available for consultation, protect confidential information, comply with reasonable instructions, and is prohibited from engaging in other employment or business activities without prior consent.

name: Enhanced Severance
description:
This parameter determines whether the enhanced severance provisions are included in the employee’s contract or policy document.

When set to true: the employment agreement will include enhanced severance clauses which go beyond the standard statutory or contractual severance entitlements. Enhanced severance benefits may include extended notice periods or payment in lieu, additional severance payments calculated by specific formulas, continuation of benefits (such as health insurance or pension contributions) after termination, and conditional requirements the Employee must satisfy to receive severance (e.g., returning employer property, complying with confidentiality obligations, signing release agreements).

When set to false: all enhanced severance clauses are excluded from the employment agreement.

Context and Operational Significance:This parameter acts as an on/off toggle to tailor severance arrangements based on employer policies, seniority, negotiation outcomes, or specific employment tiers.

Including enhanced severance provisions provides greater financial security and benefit continuity to the Employee in qualifying termination scenarios, often reflecting higher-level or executive contracts.

Excluding these provisions keeps severance terms more basic and straightforward, potentially aligning with general workforce contracts or cost-control objectives.

name: Severance Entitlement Events
description:
This parameter defines the specific circumstances or qualifying events under which an Employee becomes entitled to severance pay, in addition to any statutory redundancy payments required by law.

Purpose and Effect:
- This parameter outlines the events or reasons that trigger severance pay eligibility, such as termination due to redundancy, business closure, or other employer-initiated terminations qualifying under company policy or law.
- It helps clarify when an Employee’s severance entitlement arises, ensuring both parties understand the conditions that activate severance benefits.
- The severance pay is intended to compensate the Employee for loss of employment in specified events beyond standard notice or termination pay, often reflecting longer service or special contractual terms.

Common Examples of Severance Entitlement Events:
- Redundancy or position elimination due to business restructuring or economic reasons
- Permanent closure of the employer’s establishment or part of the business
- Termination by the Employer without cause
- Layoff exceeding a statutory or contractual duration
- Qualifying retirement or retirement with entitlement to pension benefits (in some agreements)
- Other termination scenarios specifically identified in the employment agreement or relevant statutes

name: Severance - Extended Notice Period
description:
This parameter determines whether the Employee is entitled to receive an extended notice period upon termination of employment.

When set to true:  the employment contract or policy includes a provision granting the Employee an extended notice period beyond the standard or statutory notice requirements. This means the Employee will have additional time before their employment ends, or alternatively, the Employer may provide payment in lieu of this extended notice (depending on contractual terms).

When set to false: no extended notice period is provided beyond the standard contractual or statutory minimum, and the Employee’s notice entitlement is limited accordingly.

Operational Significance:
- This parameter allows employers to customize notice period entitlements based on seniority, role, or contractual agreements.
- Including the extended notice period can provide Employees with greater security and time to transition.
- Excluding it keeps notice terms straightforward and aligned with basic legal requirements or simpler contracts.

name: Severance - Extended Notice Period Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the length of the extended notice period that an Employee is entitled to receive upon termination of employment, subject to eligibility. It sets the exact duration (such as number of weeks or months) for the enhanced or extended notice period beyond the standard or statutory notice requirements.

It determines how much additional time the Employee will have between receiving notice and the actual termination date, allowing for a smoother transition or job search period.

Alternatively, this duration can be the reference for calculating payment in lieu of notice if the Employer chooses not to require the Employee to work through the full extended notice period.

Operational Significance:
- Provides clarity and certainty on the length of extended notice entitlement within employment contracts or policies.
- Helps employers maintain consistent notice period standards for certain employee groups or roles entitled to enhanced protection.

name: Severance - Additional Payment
description:
This parameter acts as an inclusion toggle for enhanced severance benefits, helping employers tailor severance packages to certain employees, such as executives or key personnel, or based on negotiated agreements. It determines whether the employment contract or policy includes a provision granting the Employee an additional severance payment beyond statutory or standard severance entitlements.

If true: the contract or policy incorporates an additional severance payment clause, entitling the Employee to receive extra severance compensation calculated according to a predefined formula or agreed terms.

If false: this additional severance payment clause is omitted, and the Employee’s severance entitlement is limited to the statutory or existing contractual severance pay without any extra discretionary payments.

Context and Operational Significance:
- Including this clause provides greater financial security to the Employee in qualifying termination scenarios, reinforcing goodwill or satisfaction and potentially aiding retention or recruitment.
- Excluding the clause limits severance obligations to statutory minima or standard contractual terms, which may be appropriate for broader employee groups or cost-control.

name: Severance - Formula for Additional Payment
description:
This parameter specifies the method or calculation used to determine the amount of an additional severance payment to which the Employee is entitled upon termination.

Purpose and Effect:
- This parameter defines how the additional severance pay is calculated, which may involve factors such as length of service, salary multiples, fixed amounts, or other agreed formulas.
- It ensures the severance payment is computed consistently and transparently according to the established criteria or policy.
- The additional severance is typically payable on top of any statutory redundancy or severance pay, providing enhanced financial compensation to the Employee.

Operational Significance:
Helps employers manage severance costs by specifying exact or formula-based calculations rather than ad hoc amounts.
Provides Employees with clear expectations about the financial benefits they may receive upon qualifying termination.
Enables inclusion of tailored severance arrangements for specific roles, seniority levels, or negotiated agreements.

Example: The formula could be a certain number of weeks’ or months’ pay per year of service, a flat amount, or a percentage of final salary, depending on company policy or contract negotiation.

name: Post-Termination Benefits Continuation
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment contract or policy includes a clause specifying continuation of employee benefits for a period following termination.

Purpose and Effect:
- If true: the contract or policy provides that the Employer will continue to provide certain employee benefits—such as health insurance and pension contributions—for a specified duration after the Employee’s employment ends, subject to the terms, conditions, and eligibility rules of the relevant benefit plans.

If false: no such benefit continuation provision is included, and Employee benefits cease generally at termination in accordance with standard plan rules.

Context and Operational Significance:
- It enables Employers to offer enhanced severance packages that include temporary extension of benefits, providing additional security and support to the Employee during the post-employment transition period.
- Inclusion of benefit continuation can improve employee goodwill, help with retention and recruitment at senior or key levels, and align severance offerings with company policies or negotiated agreements.
- Exclusion keeps severance arrangements simpler and more aligned with typical benefit plan terminations at the end of employment.

name: Post-Termination Benefits Continuation Period
description:
This parameter specifies the length of time for which the Employer will continue providing certain employee benefits following the termination of employment.

Purpose and Effect:
- It defines the exact duration (e.g., number of weeks or months) that employee benefits—such as health insurance and pension contributions—will be maintained after the employment ends, subject to the terms and eligibility criteria of the relevant benefit plans.
- It ensures clarity regarding how long the Employee can expect continued coverage or contributions post-termination as part of an enhanced severance arrangement.
- The duration influences the Employee’s post-employment financial security and access to important benefits during their transition period.

Operational Significance:
 - Provides a transparent and measurable timeframe for benefit continuation in severance packages or employment agreements.
- Helps Employers set consistent policies for benefit extension that align with company practices or negotiated terms with Employees.
- Supports employee goodwill and retention by offering a defined benefit protection period after separation.
- Works in conjunction with eligibility rules in the benefit plans to determine actual coverage during the continuation period.

Example Usage: The contract may specify that benefits will continue for “3 months following termination” or “until the end of the next calendar year,” providing concrete expectations.

name: Collective Agreement
description:
This parameter indicates whether the Employee’s terms and conditions of employment are governed by a collective bargaining agreement.

If true: it signifies that the Employee’s employment is subject to a collective agreement negotiated between the Employer and a union, which governs core employment terms such as wages, benefits, working conditions, and dispute resolution procedures.

The Employee is bound by the collective agreement’s provisions, including any amendments or renewals, and agrees to comply with its rules and obligations during their employment.

The individual employment agreement serves as a supplement to, and must be consistent with, the collective agreement. In case of any conflict, the collective agreement’s terms prevail to the extent permitted by law.

If false: the Employee is not covered by a collective agreement, and their terms of employment are governed solely by the individual employment agreement and applicable law.

Operational Significance:
- It supports consistent enforcement of union-negotiated terms and maintains the legal primacy of collective agreements where relevant, facilitating organized labor relations.

- It distinguishes unionized employee contracts from non-unionized ones, which can impact terms, grievance processes, and representation rights.

name: Name of Collective Bargaining Agreement
description:
This parameter specifies the official title or name of the collective bargaining agreement that governs the Employee’s terms and conditions of employment.

Context and Significance:
The Employment Agreement acknowledges that the Employee’s employment terms are subject to and governed by a collective bargaining agreement (CBA). The name recorded here identifies the specific CBA, which is a negotiated contract between the Employer and the relevant trade union or employee representative body.

The CBA covers key employment conditions such as wages, working hours, leave entitlements, dispute resolution, and other workplace rights and obligations agreed upon collectively.

This parameter ties the individual employment contract to the broader collective framework negotiated by the union, ensuring legal clarity and compliance.

Purpose and Importance:
Legal and Contractual Reference: Identifies the binding collective agreement affecting the Employee’s employment, often carrying precedence or supplementing individual contract terms.

Transparency: Makes clear to the Employee which collective agreement governs their rights and obligations.

Union Relationship: Reflects the formal relationship between the Employer and the trade union representing the Employee.

Regulatory Compliance: Ensures that the employment contract acknowledges adherence to collective labor agreements as required by law in many jurisdictions.

name: Date of Collective Bargaining Agreement
description:
This parameter specifies the official date of the collective bargaining agreement that governs the Employee’s terms and conditions of employment. The date refers to when the particular collective agreement was finalized or came into effect.

Context and Function:
The Employee’s employment terms are subject to the provisions of a collective bargaining agreement concluded between the Employer and the relevant union or employee representative body. This parameter records the exact date of that collective agreement, which may be important for determining applicable rights, obligations, and any subsequent amendments or renewals of the agreement.

Purpose and Importance:
Reference Clarity: Provides a precise reference point for the specific version of the collective agreement that applies to the Employee.

Contractual Integration: Acknowledges that this collective agreement forms part of the legal framework governing the employment relationship.

Legal and Administrative Accuracy: Ensures correct identification of the collective agreement to avoid ambiguity, especially for compliance, dispute resolution, or benefit administration.

Updates and Renewals: Facilitates tracking changes when collective agreements are renegotiated or updated, by tying terms to the specific dated document.

Additional Considerations:  The date should correspond to the official signing or effective date of the collective agreement.

This parameter is typically used alongside the collective agreement name and union name for full identification.
It supports clarity for both Employer and Employee as well as any third parties reviewing the employment contract.

name: Name of Union in Collective Agreement
description:
This parameter specifies the official name of the union or labor organization that is a party to the collective bargaining agreement governing the Employee’s terms and conditions of employment.

Context and Function: The Employee acknowledges that their employment terms are subject to the provisions of a collective bargaining agreement negotiated and agreed between the Employer and a specific union or labor organization. This parameter identifies that union or organization by name.

Purpose and Importance:
Clarifies Collective Bargaining Relationship: Clearly identifies the union or labor organization whose collective agreement applies to the Employee’s employment terms.

Legal and Contractual Reference: Helps establish the source of certain employment conditions, rights, and obligations that may be set by the collective agreement rather than solely by the individual employment contract.

Employee Awareness: Ensures the Employee knows which union or labor body represents them and whose collective agreement terms shape their employment conditions.

Supports Compliance: Assists the Employer in confirming and documenting the applicable collective bargaining arrangements.

Considerations:
The name should exactly match the registered or recognized name of the union or labor organization involved.
This parameter often works jointly with other parameters such as the collective agreement title and date to precisely identify the governing collective bargaining agreement.

display.label: Name of Union in Collective Agreement

name: Work Permit Warranty
description:
It indicates whether the Employee warrants that they have the legal right to work in the specified jurisdiction without requiring additional permits, visas, or approvals.

If true: the Employee explicitly confirms that they are entitled to work legally in the jurisdiction specified by the employment agreement at the time of signing. The Employee also agrees to notify the Employer immediately if their work authorization status changes (i.e., if they cease to be entitled to work) at any time during employment.

if false: the warranty clause will be omitted from employment agreement and No such warranty is required from the Employee in the contract.

Operational Significance:
- Provides the Employer with a contractual assurance of the Employee’s work eligibility.
- Allows the Employer to act promptly in response to any loss of entitlement to work, maintaining legal compliance.
- Acts as a safeguard against penalties, fines, or legal liabilities related to unauthorized employment.

name: Professional Qualification Warranty
description:
This indicates whether the Employee is required to warrant that they hold a specific professional qualification necessary for their role at the time of entering into the employment agreement and throughout the duration of their employment.

Purpose and Effect:
If true: the Employee warrants that they possess the professional qualification specified for their position and undertake to maintain that qualification during their employment. The Employee also agrees to notify the Employer immediately if they cease to hold the required professional qualification at any time during their employment. 

If false: the clause is omitted from employment agreement. 

Operational Significance:
- Assists the Employer in confirming the Employee’s qualifications align with regulatory, professional, or company standards.
- Provides a contractual basis for Employer action if the Employee loses required qualifications or fails to notify as required.
- Supports compliance with applicable laws depending on industry or jurisdiction mandating valid professional credentials.

name: Employee Professional Qualification
description:
It specifies the particular professional qualification, license, certification, or credential that the Employee is required to hold as a condition of employment.

Purpose and Effect:
- This parameter identifies the exact professional qualification that the Employee must possess to fulfill the role’s requirements.
- It is used within clauses that require the Employee to warrant or represent that they hold this qualification at the start of employment and continue to maintain it throughout the term of employment.
- The parameter helps ensure that the Employee is legally and professionally authorized to perform their job responsibilities.
- It also supports compliance with industry regulations or legal requirements where certain roles necessitate valid professional credentials.

Operational Significance:
- Enables the inclusion of tailored contract language verifying the Employee’s qualification status.
- Provides a contractual basis for the Employer to take action (such as requiring notification or potentially terminating) if the Employee ceases to hold the required qualification.
- Facilitates clear communication of professional standards and expectations to the Employee.
- Particularly important in regulated industries (e.g., healthcare licenses, legal bar admission, engineering certifications, financial licenses).

Example Usage: "Registered Nurse", "Chartered Accountant", "Professional Engineer", "Certified Public Accountant", "Solicitor", "Barrister"

name: Warranty of Eligibility to Serve as Director
description:
It indicates whether the Employee warrants that they are not subject to any legal restrictions, disqualifications, or prohibitions preventing them from holding office as a company director.

If true: the Employee confirms that, at the time of entering the agreement (and continuing throughout employment), they are legally eligible to hold directorship positions within the relevant jurisdiction. 
This warranty helps the Employer comply with corporate governance laws and avoid risks associated with appointing disqualified directors. The Employee may also have an ongoing obligation to notify the Employer if they become restricted from holding office during employment.

If set to false: The warranty is omitted from the employment agreement. No explicit representation or assurance is made by the Employee about their eligibility to hold office as a director.
This means the Employer may not have contractual protection regarding director eligibility, and separate due diligence or provisions would be necessary if director eligibility is relevant.

display.label: Warranty of Eligibility to Serve as Director

name: Employee Indemnification for Breach of Warranties
description:
It indicates whether the Employee undertakes a contractual obligation to indemnify (compensate and hold harmless) the Employer against any claims, costs, damages, liabilities, or expenses arising from the Employee’s breach of specific warranties or obligations set out in the employment agreement.

If true: the employment agreement includes an indemnity clause obligating the Employee to cover any losses or liabilities the Employer incurs due to the Employee breaching representations such as legal work status, professional qualifications, or other contractual commitments.
This indemnity provision provides the Employer with financial and legal protection if the Employee’s warranties prove false or are violated during the course of employment. It acts as a deterrent against breaches and encourages the Employee to comply fully with their obligations.

If false: The indemnity clause is excluded from the employment contract. The Employer does not have a contractual right to claim indemnification from the Employee for breaches of these warranties under this clause, though other remedies may still apply.

Operational Significance:
- Provides an important layer of risk management for the Employer by enabling recovery of losses or defense costs linked to breaches by the Employee.
- Clarifies the Employee’s responsibility for maintaining the truth and accuracy of their warranties and obligations.
- When omitted, the Employer may need to rely on general legal remedies, which might be less direct or certain.

display.label: Employee Indemnification for Breach of Warranties

name: Prohibition on Soliciting or Receiving Inducements
description:
The Employee is prohibited at all times during their employment from directly or indirectly soliciting, accepting, or receiving any form of inducement, including discounts, rebates, commissions, or any other benefits, whether monetary or non-monetary.

Such inducements must not be solicited or accepted in exchange for actions that breach the employment agreement, involve unlawful conduct, or unfairly benefit the Employee or any third party.

Exceptions are only allowed where explicitly permitted by applicable laws or Employer policies, ensuring compliance with legal standards and internal rules.

Any benefits or inducements received under allowed circumstances must be fully and promptly disclosed to the Employer for transparency and monitoring.

This clause upholds ethical standards within the employment relationship by preventing conflicts of interest, bribery, and corruption.

It safeguards the Employer’s business interests and reputation by mitigating risks of misconduct that could cause harm or legal liabilities.

Non-compliance with this clause can lead to disciplinary action, including potential termination, and may expose the Employee to legal consequences.

Maintaining full disclosure and prohibition on unauthorized inducements fosters a culture of integrity and trust between the Employer and Employee.

display.label: Prohibition on Soliciting or Receiving Inducements

name: Prohibition on Making False Statements
description:
The Employee must not knowingly make any false or misleading statement at any time during their employment regarding the Employer or its clients.

This prohibition applies to statements about current, prospective, or former clients, ensuring all communications uphold honesty and accuracy.

False or deceptive statements may harm the Employer’s reputation, damage client trust, or cause legal liabilities.

The clause safeguards the Employer’s interests by preventing misinformation and maintaining the integrity of business relationships.

It emphasizes the importance of truthful representation in all verbal, written, and electronic communications involving the Employer or its stakeholders.

Any breach may result in disciplinary measures, including termination, and possibly legal consequences depending on the seriousness of the falsehood.

The provision fosters a culture of transparency, professionalism, and trust both inside the business and in its external dealings.

name: Prohibition on Personal Use of Employer IT Infrastructure
description:
The Employee is prohibited from using the Employer’s IT infrastructure, including computers, internet access, email accounts, and related resources, for personal or non-work-related activities.

Such prohibited activities encompass streaming videos, listening to podcasts, posting on blogs, wikis, social networks, forums, message boards, commenting on articles, or forwarding emails not related to work duties.

This policy ensures that IT resources are allocated primarily for business and work-related functions, promoting operational efficiency and productivity.

Limiting personal use helps reduce security risks such as malware infection or data breaches that can result from non-work-related internet usage.

Restricting personal usage also minimizes network congestion and prevents misuse of company resources that could affect system performance and availability to others.

The clause emphasizes that any personal use must be expressly authorized by the Employer, otherwise it is strictly forbidden.

Adherence to this policy helps the organization maintain a secure, professional, and compliant IT environment.

The policy contributes to the safeguarding of confidential and proprietary company information by preventing access through unauthorized or excessive personal activities.

Employees violating this clause may be subject to disciplinary action consistent with company policies and the severity of the breach.

display.label: Prohibition on Personal Use of Employer IT Infrastructure

name: Prohibition on Online Disclosure of Confidential Info
description:
The Employee is strictly prohibited from disclosing any Confidential Information related to the Employer or its clients during personal, non-work-related online activities.

Confidential Information includes any proprietary data, trade secrets, client details, business plans, technical knowledge, or other sensitive information not publicly available.

While engaging in online communication for personal purposes—such as on social media, blogs, forums, or other platforms—the Employee must not represent or suggest that their statements or views reflect the opinions, positions, or affiliations of the Employer.

This clause safeguards the Employer’s confidential information from unauthorized public exposure that could damage business interests or client relationships.

It enforces the clear separation between the Employee's personal views and the official stance of the Employer to prevent confusion or misrepresentation.

Employees are expected to exercise discretion in their online presence to protect the Employer’s reputation and maintain professional boundaries.

Breaches of this clause may lead to disciplinary action, including termination, depending on the severity and impact of the disclosure or misrepresentation.

This provision promotes trust, confidentiality, and integrity in all digital communications connected with the Employee’s association with the Employer.

display.label: Prohibition on Online Disclosure of Confidential Info

name: Penalties for Breach of Online Conduct
description:
Any breach of this clause, including offensive or inappropriate online conduct by the Employee, is categorized as Serious Misconduct, indicating a severe violation of workplace standards.

Serious Misconduct fundamentally undermines the employment relationship and may justify immediate disciplinary action, including summary dismissal without compensation or notice.

At the sole discretion of the Employer, the Employee may be summarily dismissed for such breaches, reflecting the gravity of the misconduct.

The Employer may also require the Employee to issue a written apology, at their own expense, which clearly disavows the offensive comments or conduct.

The apology must affirm that the views expressed are solely those of the Employee and do not represent or reflect the Employer in any way.

This clause serves to maintain the Employer’s reputation and uphold professional standards of conduct in all online and digital communications.

It provides clear consequences to deter inappropriate behavior and protect the company’s interests in the digital space.

The policy emphasizes the importance of responsible online behavior by Employees both during and related to their employment.

display.label: Penalties for Breach of Online Conduct

name: Employee Confidentiality Obligation
description:
This parameter controls whether the Employment Agreement includes a comprehensive confidentiality obligation binding the Employee to protect the Employer’s Confidential Information during and after employment.

if true: (Confidentiality Obligation Included): The Employee acknowledges access to and responsibility for safeguarding Confidential Information entrusted to them during the course of employment.
The Employee agrees not to disclose or use any Confidential Information related to the Employer or its related parties except as authorized in the proper performance of their duties or as required by law.
The Employee must keep such information strictly confidential, only sharing it with authorized persons who have a legitimate need to know and who are themselves bound by confidentiality obligations.
Reasonable precautions, including compliance with Employer policies and procedures, must be taken by the Employee to protect confidential data.
Upon request and upon termination of employment, the Employee is required to return all Confidential Information in their possession.
The Employee agrees not to disclose the terms and conditions of their employment to any third party without prior written consent of the Employer, except as required by law.
Breach of these confidentiality obligations may lead to disciplinary action including summary dismissal, and potential claims for damages.
The confidentiality obligations survive termination of employment indefinitely or at least for as long as the information remains confidential.

If false: Confidentiality Obligation Excluded: The Employment Agreement does not include the specified confidentiality obligations protecting the Employer’s sensitive information.
The Employee may not be contractually bound to maintain confidentiality beyond general legal duties, reducing the contractual safeguards around sensitive information.

Purpose and Importance:
Protects Sensitive Information: Ensures the Employer’s trade secrets, business data, and proprietary information are kept secure.

Defines Clear Employee Responsibilities: Clarifies the Employee’s role in preserving confidentiality and handling sensitive information with care.

Establishes Post-Employment Obligations: Extends confidentiality duties beyond the term of employment to safeguard ongoing business interests.

Supports Enforcement and Remedies: Sets out consequences of breach, providing the Employer with grounds for disciplinary measures and indemnity claims.

name: Scope of Related Parties for Confidentiality
description:
This parameter specifies the categories of entities or individuals associated with the Employer whose confidential information is also protected under the Employee’s confidentiality obligations. It defines the scope of confidentiality protection beyond the Employer itself, extending it to parties related to the Employer. It typically includes entities such as the Employer’s clients, suppliers, employees, affiliates, subsidiaries, and other relevant connected parties.

By explicitly listing these related parties, the parameter ensures that the Employee understands that confidential information pertaining to these associated parties must also be safeguarded.

Protecting information about related parties is crucial as such information can be commercially sensitive and integral to the Employer’s business relationships and competitive standing.

Default Value: often defined as “clients, suppliers, employees, or affiliates”
This covers a broad and common set of related parties typically involved in business operations and whose information needs protection.

Operational Significance:
Helps tailor confidentiality clauses by clearly defining the breadth of the confidential information subject to non-disclosure.
Provides clarity for the Employee on the extent of information covered under confidentiality duties, reducing ambiguity and risk of inadvertent breaches.
Enables the Employer to protect relationships and proprietary information concerning not just itself but key business partners and internal stakeholders.

display.label: Scope of Related Parties for Confidentiality

name: Employer Property Ownership and Return
description:
This parameter specifies whether the Employment Agreement includes a clause regarding the ownership of Employer property used or accessed by the Employee during the course of employment, and the Employee’s obligation to return such property.

When set to TRUE (Include Employer Property Clause):
The Agreement confirms that all physical and digital property provided by the Employer to the Employee—such as documents, manuals, hardware, software, and data—is the exclusive property of the Employer.
This includes any materials produced, maintained, or stored on the Employer’s computer systems or electronic devices during employment.
The Employee is obligated to return all such property, as well as any copies or materials containing Confidential Information, immediately upon termination of employment or upon the Employer’s request at any time.
This clause protects the Employer’s ownership rights and ensures the preservation of proprietary information and assets.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Employer Property Clause):
The Agreement does not explicitly include provisions regarding ownership and return of Employer-provided property.
Return obligations and ownership rights may need to be addressed separately or through other policies.

Purpose and Importance:
Protects Employer Assets: Ensures that all Employer property remains protected, reducing the risk of loss, unauthorized use, or misappropriation.

Clarifies Employee Obligations: Clearly defines the Employee’s duty to return all Employer property promptly, preventing disputes at the end of employment.

Supports Confidentiality and Security: Reinforces the safeguarding of confidential information stored on Employer equipment or systems.

Legal and Operational Compliance: Aligns with legal practices to maintain control over business assets and intellectual property.

name: Restriction on Outside Employment and Engagement
description:
The Employee shall not engage, either directly or indirectly, in any other business, profession, or enterprise besides their role with the Employer without first obtaining the Employer’s prior express written consent.

This restriction aims to prevent conflicts of interest, divided loyalties, and interference with the Employee’s responsibilities toward the Employer.

It applies broadly to any form of outside employment, business ownership, consultancy, investment, or involvement in enterprises that may compete with or otherwise affect the Employer’s interests.

The clause ensures the Employee’s focus, dedication, and availability are primarily toward the Employer’s business activities during the course of their employment.

The requirement for prior written consent allows the Employer to assess the nature of potential outside engagements and manage any risks associated with competing interests or diminished performance.

Unauthorized outside engagements can lead to disciplinary actions, including possible termination, given the breach of contract and fiduciary duties.

The provision safeguards the Employer’s confidential information, trade secrets, and overall competitive position by limiting the Employee’s external business activities.

It fosters transparency and accountability, obliging the Employee to disclose and seek approval for any external business interests or employment.

This clause helps maintain a clear boundary between the Employee’s personal business activities and their obligations under the employment agreement.

display.label: Restriction on Outside Employment and Engagement

name: Employer’s Best Interest and Avoid Conflicts of Interest
description:
The Employee is obligated at all times to act in the best interests of the Employer, prioritizing the Employer’s welfare, business goals, and reputation in all professional conduct.

The Employee must actively avoid any situation or activity that constitutes, or could reasonably be perceived to constitute, a conflict between their personal interests and those of the Employer.

This includes avoiding actual conflicts, potential conflicts, and situations that might give an appearance or perception of conflicting interests, even if no wrongdoing occurs.

The Employee shall not cause or permit any circumstance that could lead to an actual, potential, or perceived conflict of interest, ensuring transparency and integrity in their employment relationship.

The clause aims to prevent compromised decision-making, bias, favoritism, or divided loyalty that could undermine the Employer’s trust and the Employee’s professional judgment.

It reinforces the Employee’s fiduciary duty to safeguard the Employer’s confidential information, resources, and business opportunities without improper personal gain.

Employees must disclose any known or potential conflicts of interest promptly and cooperate with the Employer to resolve or manage such conflicts appropriately.

Failure to comply with this obligation may lead to disciplinary measures, including termination, depending on the severity and impact of the conflict.

This provision supports a culture of ethical behavior, accountability, and fairness, helping maintain the Employer’s reputation and lawful business operations.

display.label: Employer's Best Interest and Avoid Conflicts of Interest

name: Conflict of Interests
description:
This parameter controls whether the conflict of interest clause is included in the employment agreement. It dictates whether the Employee is contractually bound to avoid and disclose conflicts of interest during their employment.

If true: the employment contract includes a comprehensive conflict of interest clause requiring the Employee to:
- Act in the best interests of the Employer at all times.
- Avoid any actual, potential, or perceived conflicts between their personal interests and those of the Employer.
- Promptly disclose any such conflicts to the designated manager.
- Comply with the Employer’s conflict of interest policy and instructions.
- Understand that failure to comply may lead to disciplinary action, including summary dismissal.

If false: the contract excludes these specific conflict of interest obligations. The Employer may choose to manage conflicts of interest under separate policies or agreements, or not incorporate these provisions directly in the employment contract.

Operational Significance:
Including this clause (true) ensures clear contractual expectations around Employee loyalty, transparency, and ethical conduct. It helps the Employer proactively manage risks related to conflicting loyalties, financial interests, or outside engagements that could affect performance or reputation.

Excluding this clause (false) means reliance on other mechanisms (e.g., staff handbooks, codes of conduct) rather than contractual enforcement.

Practical Effect:
If true: The Employee must be aware of conflict of interest rules and disclosure procedures embedded in their contract, with enforceable consequences for breaches.

If false: While conflict of interest concerns may still be addressed by company policies, the Employee is not contractually mandated to comply via the employment agreement.

name: Non-Compete
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a Non-Compete clause that restricts the Employee from engaging in competitive business activities during the term of employment and for a specified period following termination.

If TRUE: Include Non-Compete Clause:
- The agreement explicitly prohibits the Employee from, during employment and for a defined post-termination period, personally or indirectly participating in or having any interest in any business that competes with the Employer or its affiliates and subsidiaries.
- This restriction applies to all competitive activities such as working, contracting, or cooperating with competitors within a specified geographic territory relevant to the Employer's business.
- The clause also includes a provision that, if the Employee breaches this restriction, they must compensate the Employer financially with an amount calculated by an agreed penalty formula.
- This inclusion helps protect the Employer’s confidential information, customer base, goodwill, and competitive position.

If FALSE (Exclude Non-Compete Clause):
- The employment agreement will omit the Non-Compete clause entirely.
- No contractual restriction will be imposed on the Employee from engaging in competitive activities during or after employment as part of this agreement.
- The Employer may rely on other mechanisms such as general legal obligations or separate agreements to protect its business interests.

Considerations and Recommendations:
- Non-Compete clauses may face legal restrictions or limitations depending on the jurisdiction. Some regions restrict or prohibit non-compete agreements, particularly their duration and scope.
- Employers should use this parameter with caution and consult local legal advice to ensure the clause’s enforceability.
- Including the clause is generally recommended for roles with access to sensitive business information or key relationships, especially senior or strategic positions.
- Excluding the clause may suit junior or temporary roles or when such restrictions would be unenforceable or impractical.

name: Non-Compete Period (Post-Termination)
description:
This parameter specifies the duration for which the Employee is restricted from engaging in any business or activity that competes with the Employer’s business after the termination of employment.

Accepted Values: The duration value should include both the length and the time unit, such as days, months, or years (e.g., "6 months", "1 year", "90 days").

Purpose and Use:  
Defines the length of the post-employment non-compete restriction period during which the Employee must refrain from working with competitors, either personally or through agents or collaborators.
Helps protect the Employer’s confidential information, client relationships, and business goodwill by limiting immediate competition from former employees.

Important Notes:
The period chosen should be reasonable and proportionate to protect legitimate business interests without being overly restrictive, as enforceability depends on local jurisdictional laws.
Some jurisdictions impose legal limits on non-compete durations; therefore, it is important to select a period compliant with applicable laws.

name: Non-Compete Territory
description:
This parameter specifies the geographic area or territory within which the Employee is restricted from engaging in any business or activity that competes with the Employer’s business during employment and for a specified period after termination.

Purpose and Use:
- Defines the spatial scope of the non-compete obligation, limiting where the Employee cannot work for, contract with, or have interests in competitor businesses.
- Typically includes regions where the Employer operates, which could be countries, states, provinces, cities, or any other relevant market or operational area.
- Helps protect the Employer’s business interests, customer relationships, trade secrets, and goodwill within the designated area.

Important Notes:
- The territory should be reasonable and proportionate to protect legitimate business interests without overly restricting the Employee’s ability to work.
- Courts in many jurisdictions review the geographic scope for enforceability, with overly broad or indefinite territories often being struck down.
- Jurisdictional laws differ; some regions impose stricter limits or require precise definitions of the non-compete territory.
- Employers should tailor and review this parameter with local legal advice to ensure compliance and practical enforceability.

name: List of Competitors - Non-Compete Clause
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement references an attached List of Competitors that defines the specific entities and individuals deemed as competitors for purposes of the non-competition restrictions.

When enabled (true), the non-compete clause applies exclusively to the entities and individuals identified in the attached list, providing clear and specific boundaries for restricted competitive activities.

This specificity helps avoid ambiguity and overly broad restrictions by clearly identifying the businesses considered competitors based on how their operations impact the Employer’s market and interests.

When disabled (false), the non-compete clause may operate more generally without an explicit competitor list, relying instead on broader definitions of competing businesses or industries.

Including a competitor list enhances enforceability by tailoring the scope of restrictions to relevant market players and informing the Employee precisely which businesses are covered.

The list can be updated as needed to reflect changes in the competitive landscape, ensuring ongoing relevance of the restriction.

name: Non-Compete Breach Remedy
description:
This parameter governs whether the employment agreement includes a comprehensive remedy provision for breach of the non-competition clause.

If enabled (true), it allows the non-breaching Party (typically the Employer) to seek immediate injunctive relief to prevent ongoing or threatened breaches without the burden of proving actual damages or posting a bond.

It entitles the Employer to recover damages, including reasonable legal fees incurred in enforcing the non-compete agreement.

Additionally, the breaching Party is obligated to pay liquidated damages calculated by a predetermined formula, representing a genuine pre-estimate of loss caused by the breach.

These remedies are cumulative and supplementary to any other available rights or legal actions, providing robust protection against violations.

When disabled (false), such explicit remedies may not be included, potentially limiting the Employer’s enforcement options and delay relief for breaches.

name: Non-Compete Breach Penalty Formula
description:
This parameter specifies the formula or method used to calculate the monetary compensation payable by the Employee to the Employer in the event of a breach of the non-compete obligations.

Purpose and Use:
- Defines how the penalty amount is determined if the Employee violates the non-compete clause.
- Typically expressed as a calculation based on salary or other quantifiable metrics (e.g., "X months’ total salary", "base salary multiplied by Y", or a fixed monetary sum).
- Provides a clear and predetermined financial consequence designed to deter breaches and offer compensation for potential harm or loss to the Employer.

Examples of Common Formulas:
- A fixed number of months’ salary (e.g., "6 months’ total salary").
- A multiple of the Employee’s last drawn total remuneration.
- A specific fixed amount agreed upon in advance.

Important Notes:
- The formula should be reasonable and justifiable to increase the likelihood of enforceability.
- Some jurisdictions regulate penalty or liquidated damages clauses; amounts deemed punitive or disproportionate may be struck down or reduced by courts.
- Employers should design the formula to reflect a genuine pre-estimate of loss rather than as a penalty.
- Clear specification of the calculation basis (e.g., total salary inclusive of bonuses or commissions) helps avoid disputes.

name: Non-Solicitation Restriction
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a non-solicitation clause restricting the Employee from soliciting or contacting the Employer’s Company Business Partners.

When enabled (true), the Employee is prohibited, both during employment and for a defined period after termination, from directly or indirectly soliciting or contacting any Company Business Partners with the intent to induce them to cease, reduce, or alter their business relationship with the Employer without prior written consent.

This restriction protects the Employer’s established commercial relationships, ensuring that the Employee does not unfairly divert clients or business opportunities for personal or competitor gain.

Enabling this clause helps safeguard goodwill, client loyalty, and the Employer’s investment in building business partnerships.

When disabled (false), this non-solicitation restriction is omitted from the agreement, potentially allowing the Employee to engage with the Employer’s clients or partners post-employment.

The scope and duration of this restriction are typically reasonable and time-bound to balance protection of business interests with the Employee’s right to seek employment.

name: Non-Solicitation Period (Post-Termination)
description:
This parameter specifies the duration for which the Employee is restricted from soliciting the Employer’s employees, customers, or business partners during employment and for a defined period following the termination of employment, regardless of the reason for termination.

Accepted Values: The value should include a length and time unit, such as days, months, or years (e.g., "6 months", "1 year", "90 days").

Purpose and Use:
- Defines the time period during which the Employee must not directly or indirectly solicit or interfere with the Employer’s employees, customers, or business relationships without prior written authorization.
- Helps protect the Employer’s workforce stability, client base, and commercial goodwill from disruption caused by employee departure.

Important Notes:
- The length of the non-solicitation period should be reasonable and proportionate to protect legitimate business interests without overly restricting the Employee’s ability to work.
- Enforceability varies by jurisdiction; some regions impose limits on the duration or scope of such restrictions.
- Employers should configure this period considering local laws and best practice to ensure valid and enforceable agreements.

name: Non-Dealing Restriction
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a non-solicitation and non-dealing clause restricting the Employee from entering into business dealings with the Employer’s Company Business Partners.

When enabled (true), the Employee is prohibited during employment and for a set period after termination from entering into any contract, agreement, or business arrangement with the Employer’s Company Business Partners involving goods or services that compete with or are substantially similar to those provided by the Employer, without prior written approval.

This clause provides robust protection by preventing both active solicitation and passive business dealings, ensuring the Employee cannot indirectly circumvent restrictions by allowing the business partner to approach them for competitive transactions.

It helps safeguard valuable client and partner relationships, business goodwill, and confidential information, minimizing risk of competitive harm post-employment.

When disabled (false), such non-solicit non-dealing restrictions are omitted, enabling the Employee potentially to engage with former business partners after leaving the Employer.

The scope and duration are intended to be reasonable and proportionate, balancing the Employer’s legitimate business interests with the Employee’s right to future work opportunities.

name: Non-Dealing Restriction Period
description:
This parameter defines the length of time following termination of employment during which the Employee is prohibited from entering into business contracts, agreements, or arrangements with the Employer’s Company Business Partners involving competing or substantially similar goods or services.

The non-dealing period allows the Employer to protect its business relationships and market position by preventing the Employee from indirectly competing through existing clients or partners shortly after leaving.

This timeframe helps stabilize the Employer’s customer base, giving sufficient opportunity to maintain or rebuild loyalty and business connections without interference from the former Employee.

The period typically balances protecting legitimate business interests and avoiding undue restrictions on the Employee’s right to engage in commerce post-employment.

A 12-month duration is widely regarded as reasonable and commonly used in non-dealing and restrictive covenant clauses to enhance enforceability.

The specific length may be adjusted based on industry standards, nature of the business, and jurisdictional considerations.

name: Company Business Partners List
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes an attached List of Company Business Partners that defines the specific clients, customers, suppliers, and partners to whom the contractual restrictions apply.

When enabled (true), the entities and individuals in the attached list are recognized as the Company Business Partners subject to non-solicitation, non-dealing, or similar restrictions with respect to the Employee.

The list provides clarity and precision regarding which business partners are covered, helping avoid ambiguity and ensuring the Employee understands the specific restricted parties.

The provision also states that the list is not exhaustive and does not limit the broader scope of non-solicitation obligations, which are determined by the Company’s actual business relationships and activities.

The Company reserves the right to amend, supplement, or update the list at its discretion, with an obligation to provide updated copies to the Employee upon request, maintaining transparency and adaptability.

When disabled (false), the agreement does not include a specific attached list, and restrictions apply more generally, without tailored identification of business partners.

name: Non-Solicitation of Staff
description:
This parameter controls the inclusion of a clause prohibiting the Employee from soliciting, inducing, or encouraging any of the Employer’s employees to terminate their employment or engagement.

When enabled (true), the Employee is restricted during employment and for a specified period after termination from directly or indirectly soliciting the Employer’s staff to leave, without the Employer’s express written permission.

This provision protects the Employer’s workforce stability and investment in human capital by preventing employee poaching and disruption to business operations.

The non-solicitation period, specified by a parameter such as employment_non_poaching_period, balances protection of the Employer’s interests with the Employee’s post-employment freedoms.

When disabled (false), this restriction is omitted, allowing the Employee more freedom to engage with former colleagues post-employment.

This parameter is especially crucial in industries where employee relationships and team cohesion are key to business success.

name: Staff Non-Solicitation Period
description:
This parameter sets the duration following the termination of employment during which the Employee is restricted from soliciting, inducing, or encouraging the Employer’s employees to leave their employment or engagement.

The non-poaching period protects the Employer’s workforce stability by preventing former employees from poaching current staff for a reasonable post-termination timeframe.

This restriction helps maintain business continuity, morale, and retention of key personnel shortly after the departure of the Employee.

The default 12-month duration is widely accepted as reasonable to balance protecting legitimate business interests and allowing the Employee future career mobility.

The parameter supports enforceability of the non-poaching clause by defining a clear temporal boundary aligned with common legal standards in restrictive covenants.

It is important that this period is not excessively long to avoid being deemed an unreasonable restraint on trade or employment.

name: Non-Solicitation Remedy
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement contains a provision granting the Employer remedies for breaches of non-solicitation obligations by the Employee.

When enabled (true), the Employer is entitled to seek injunctive relief and any other available legal or equitable remedies without the need to post a bond or prove actual damages, facilitating prompt judicial intervention to prevent or stop harm caused by breaches.

In addition to injunctive relief, the Employer may recover monetary damages, including reasonable legal fees incurred in enforcing the clause.

The breaching Employee shall pay liquidated damages calculated by a predefined formula, representing a genuine pre-estimate of the Employer’s loss, providing certainty about financial consequences.

These remedies are cumulative and in addition to any other rights the Employer may have, ensuring comprehensive protection of business interests.

When disabled (false), the agreement does not include these specific remedial provisions, which may limit the Employer’s ability to swiftly enforce non-solicitation restrictions.

name: Non-Solicitation Breach Penalty Formula
description:
This parameter specifies the formula or fixed amount used to calculate the liquidated damages payable by the breaching party upon violation of the non-solicitation clause.

It serves as a pre-agreed estimate of damages the Employer may suffer due to a breach of non-solicitation obligations, facilitating quicker resolution without requiring proof of actual loss.

The formula should be reasonable and proportionate to the potential harm caused, ensuring it is enforceable and not deemed a punitive penalty by courts.

Common formulas may consider factors such as a percentage of the breaching Employee’s salary, a fixed sum, or a calculation tied to the value of lost business or clients.

This parameter provides clarity and certainty for both Parties on the financial consequences of breach, encouraging compliance and reducing litigation risks.

Careful drafting and justification of the amount or formula are critical, as courts scrutinize liquidated damages provisions to ensure they reflect a genuine pre-estimate of loss rather than punishment.

In summary, this parameter defines the agreed method for calculating monetary damages for non-solicitation breaches, supporting enforceable and predictable remedies for the Employer.### Title: Non-Solicitation Penalty Formula Parameter

name: Non-Disparagement
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement imposes non-disparagement obligations on the Employee and, optionally, on the Employer.

When enabled (true), the Employee is prohibited during employment and for a defined period afterwards from making direct or indirect statements or communications that disparage or harm the reputation or goodwill of the Employer or its affiliates.

The clause includes important exceptions allowing truthful statements in legal proceedings, whistleblowing, or as otherwise required by law, protecting the Employee's legal rights.

It may include a mutual non-disparagement obligation requiring the Employer and its officers, directors, employees, and agents to also refrain from disparaging the Employee during the same period.

Remedies for breach often include injunctive relief and other legal or equitable remedies without the need to prove actual damages, acknowledging the potential for irreparable harm.

When disabled (false), no such restriction on disparaging statements is imposed in the agreement, potentially allowing unfettered communications post-employment.

name: Non-Disparagement Duration
description:
This parameter defines the length of time following the termination of employment during which the Employee is prohibited from making disparaging statements or communications about the Employer or its affiliates.

The duration typically begins upon termination and extends for a reasonable period, commonly 12 months, to protect the Employer’s reputation and goodwill during the transition period after the Employee’s departure.

This time frame balances the Employer’s interest in preserving its image with the Employee’s free speech rights, ensuring the clause is enforceable and not overly restrictive.

The parameter applies to statements made directly or indirectly that could harm the Employer’s business standing, including oral, written, public, or private communications.

Exceptions often exist within the clause to allow truthful statements made in legal proceedings, whistleblowing, or as otherwise required by law, protecting essential legal rights.

Defining this parameter clearly helps establish enforceability boundaries and sets expectations for both Parties regarding post-employment conduct related to reputation.

name: Non-Disparagement Exceptions
description:
This  parameter controls the inclusion of exceptions to the non-disparagement obligations, ensuring employee rights are protected within the employment agreement.

When enabled (true), the Employee is explicitly allowed to make truthful statements required by law or in response to valid legal processes, such as subpoenas.

It permits communications with government or regulatory authorities as part of lawful whistleblowing or reporting obligations, protecting public interest and compliance.

The parameter safeguards the Employee’s rights to exercise protections under applicable employment laws, including reporting unlawful or unethical conduct, ensuring the clause does not unlawfully restrict these actions.

Including these exceptions makes the non-disparagement clause lawful and enforceable, balancing the Employer’s interest in reputation protection with statutory employee rights.

When disabled (false), such exceptions may be omitted, risking unenforceability or conflict with legal protections.

name: Mutual Non-Disparagement
description:
This boolean parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a mutual non-disparagement clause, requiring both the Employer and Employee to refrain from making disparaging statements about each other.

When enabled (true), the Employer agrees that its officers, directors, employees, and agents will also refrain from making any disparaging or derogatory statements about the Employee during the same post-employment period as the Employee’s non-disparagement obligations.

This mutual provision promotes fairness and respect, reducing the risk of retaliatory or harmful comments from either party and helping to preserve professional reputations on both sides.

Such clauses typically apply during employment and a specified period following termination, balancing protection of goodwill with freedom of expression.

When disabled (false), the non-disparagement obligation applies only to the Employee, and the Employer does not undertake reciprocal non-disparagement commitments.

Inclusion of this parameter encourages more amicable separations and supports ongoing professional goodwill post-employment.

name: Non-Disparagement Remedy
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a remedial provision granting the non-breaching party rights and remedies if the non-disparagement clause is violated.

When enabled (true), the non-breaching party may seek injunctive relief (court orders to stop disparaging conduct) and other available legal or equitable remedies without the need to post a bond or prove actual damages, facilitating swift enforcement.

Remedies are cumulative, allowing the non-breaching party to pursue one or more remedies simultaneously or sequentially, alongside any other contractual or legal rights.

This provision acknowledges the serious and often irreparable harm that disparaging statements can cause to reputation and business interests, supporting effective deterrence and protection.

When disabled (false), the agreement lacks specific enforcement remedies tied to non-disparagement breaches, potentially limiting recourse and weakening the clause’s practical effect.

name: Intellectual Property Ownership and Assignment
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a clause that establishes the Employer's ownership rights over all Intellectual Property (IP) created by the Employee during the course of their employment and formalizes the assignment of such IP rights from the Employee to the Employer.

When set to TRUE (Include IP Ownership and Assignment Clause):
- The agreement explicitly states that all IP rights—such as inventions, designs, works of authorship, trade secrets, improvements, discoveries, and know-how—conceived, created, developed or reduced to practice by the Employee alone or jointly during employment, will be the exclusive property of the Employer.
- This ownership applies regardless of where, when, or using whose resources the IP was created (including Employer premises, work hours, or Employer resources).
- The Employee irrevocably assigns all rights, titles, and interests in these IP rights to the Employer immediately and agrees to execute any documents or take actions necessary to perfect and protect the Employer’s ownership, both during and after employment.
- This clause safeguards the Employer’s proprietary innovations and enables effective protection, commercial exploitation, and enforcement of their IP rights.

When set to FALSE (Exclude IP Ownership and Assignment Clause):
- The employment agreement will omit this explicit clause.
- The Employee’s creation of IP during employment is not formally assigned to the Employer by contract within this agreement.
- Ownership of Intellectual Property may still be governed by applicable local laws or separate agreements, but no explicit assignment or ownership clause is included.

Considerations and Recommendations:
- Inclusion of this clause is strongly advised for roles involving research, development, creative work, or access to sensitive proprietary information.
- The scope and enforceability of IP ownership and assignment provisions may vary depending on jurisdictional laws and public policy limitations.
- Employers should ensure the clause is clearly drafted, balanced, and complies with local legal requirements to maximize enforceability.

name: Waiver of Moral Rights in IP
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement contains a clause where the Employee waives their moral rights in Intellectual Property created during employment and agrees to reasonably assist the Employer in registering and enforcing those rights.

When set to TRUE (Include Clause):
- The Employee waives moral rights (such as rights of attribution and integrity) to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, allowing the Employer to use, modify, and commercialize the IP without restrictions related to these personal rights.
- The Employee agrees to provide reasonable assistance—including executing documents and cooperating in legal or administrative proceedings—necessary for the registration, protection, and enforcement of the Employer’s IP rights.
- This assistance obligation applies both during employment and after termination.
- The clause helps ensure the Employer can fully exploit and protect Intellectual Property without impediments.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Clause):
- The Employee retains moral rights to the Intellectual Property by default, which may limit the Employer’s use or modification of such IP without further consent.
- There is no contractual obligation on the Employee to assist with registration or enforcement matters.
- This could complicate enforcing or commercializing IP developed by the Employee.

Considerations:
- Moral rights vary by jurisdiction, and in some locations, cannot be fully waived. This clause is designed to comply with such limits.
- Inclusion is usually recommended to provide clear legal certainty and operational flexibility for the Employer.

display.label: Waiver of Moral Rights in IP

name: Pre-Existing Intellectual Property Disclosure
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement requires the Employee to disclose any Intellectual Property (IP) they developed or owned prior to starting employment that will be used during their employment. It also clarifies ownership rights regarding such pre-existing IP.

When set to TRUE (Include Pre-Existing IP Disclosure Clause):
- The Employee must provide a written disclosure at the outset of employment listing all pre-existing Intellectual Property they own or control that is intended to be used during the course of their employment.
- The Employee formally represents and warrants that this disclosure is complete and accurate, covering all relevant patent, trademark, copyright, trade secret, and other proprietary rights developed before joining.
- The Employer does not claim ownership of any disclosed pre-existing IP unless explicitly agreed otherwise in writing.
- This clause helps establish clear boundaries between the Employee’s prior IP and new IP developed during employment, reducing risk of ownership disputes.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Pre-Existing IP Disclosure Clause):
- The employment agreement will not include any explicit requirement for the Employee to disclose pre-existing IP at the start of employment.
- There may be uncertainty or lack of clarity regarding ownership and use of IP created before employment but used during it.
- Ownership of such IP may be subject to local law defaults or separate agreements, potentially increasing conflict risks.

Considerations and Recommendations:
- Including this clause is generally advisable in roles involving use or creation of intellectual property to provide legal clarity and protect both parties.
- The scope and enforceability of the clause should be reviewed for compliance with relevant jurisdictional laws.
- Timely disclosure at the outset of employment is critical for effective IP management.

name: Employee Personal IP Disclosure and Consent
description:
This parameter determines whether the employment agreement includes a clause requiring the Employee to notify the Employer in advance if they intend to create or develop any Intellectual Property (IP) in their own personal time and with their own resources, and to obtain the Employer’s written consent before commencing such work if the Employee wishes to retain sole ownership.

When set to TRUE (Include Personal IP Disclosure Clause):
- The agreement mandates that the Employee must provide prior written notice to the Employer regarding any intended creation or development of personal IP outside the scope of their employment, using personal time and resources.
- The Employee is prohibited from starting work on such personal IP projects until the Employer confirms in writing that it has no claim or interest in those works.
