- This clause helps protect the Employee’s rights to personal projects while ensuring the Employer can assess any potential conflicts with its business or proprietary interests.
- It reduces the risk of later disputes concerning ownership or claims over the Employee’s independently created Intellectual Property.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Personal IP Disclosure Clause):
- The employment agreement does not impose a formal obligation on the Employee to notify or obtain consent from the Employer before creating personal Intellectual Property.
- The Employee may proceed with personal IP projects without written approval or prior notification.
- This could increase the risk of disputes if the Employer later claims an interest or ownership in personal IP developed by the Employee.

Considerations and Recommendations:
- This clause is particularly important for roles where employees have opportunities or motivation to innovate independently but where the Employer’s business and confidential information could overlap with such efforts.
- The requirement for prior written notice and consent should be applied reasonably to balance the Employee’s personal creative freedoms and the Employer’s legitimate business interests.
- The clause should be crafted in accordance with local laws and regulations regarding IP ownership and employee rights.

display.label: Employee Personal IP Disclosure and Consent

name: Employer’s Right to Assign Employment Agreement
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a provision that allows the Employer to assign or transfer the Agreement, in whole or in part, to another entity without needing the Employee’s prior consent. This commonly occurs in connection with corporate actions such as mergers, acquisitions, reorganizations, or restructurings.

When set to TRUE (Include Clause):
- The Employer explicitly reserves the right to assign or transfer all or part of the Employment Agreement to any third party or related entity in the event of corporate actions.
- The assignment or transfer does not change the terms and conditions of the Agreement.
- The Employee remains bound by all provisions of the Agreement regardless of such assignment or transfer.
- This clause provides the Employer with operational flexibility and continuity of employment relationships despite changes in business ownership or structure.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Clause):
- The agreement does not expressly allow the Employer to assign or transfer the contract without the Employee’s consent.
- Any transfer of rights or obligations by the Employer may require the Employee’s prior approval or be subject to law.
- This may limit the Employer’s flexibility in corporate restructuring scenarios.

Considerations:
- This clause is standard in employment contracts, especially for businesses anticipating corporate restructuring or sale.
- Ensures seamless transition of employment obligations without disrupting the Employee’s contract.
- Jurisdictional laws may affect enforceability; local legal advice may be necessary.

display.label: Employer's Right to Assign Employment Agreement

name: Restriction on Employee’s Assignment of Employment Agreement
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a clause that prohibits the Employee from assigning, transferring, or delegating their services, rights, or obligations under the Agreement to any third party without the prior written consent of the Employer.

When set to TRUE (Include Clause):
- The Employee acknowledges that the services they provide are personal in nature and cannot be assigned or delegated to another individual or entity without the Employer’s explicit prior written approval.
- The Employee is prohibited from transferring or assigning any contractual rights or duties under the Agreement without this consent.
- Any attempted assignment, transfer, or delegation by the Employee without such consent is legally null and void.
- This clause ensures that the Employer maintains control over who performs the contracted services and preserves the integrity and accountability of the employment relationship.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Clause):
- The employment agreement does not include explicit restrictions on the Employee’s ability to assign, transfer, or delegate their rights or obligations.
- The Employee may be able to transfer or delegate services or contract rights without the Employer’s prior consent, subject to applicable law.
- This could risk services being performed by unauthorized third parties or complicate enforcement of contractual obligations.

Considerations:
- This clause is standard in employment contracts, especially for roles where personal skills, trust, confidentiality, or fiduciary duties are central.
- Including this clause protects the Employer’s interest in ensuring that only the contracted Employee performs the job duties.
- The clause complements the Employer’s right to assign the contract but limits the Employee’s right to do the same.

display.label: Restriction on Employee's Assignment of Employment Agreement

name: Force Majeure
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a Force Majeure clause that protects both Employer and Employee from liability or breach of contract if performance is prevented or delayed due to extraordinary events beyond their control.

When set to TRUE (Include Force Majeure Clause):
- The agreement specifies that neither party shall be liable for failure or delay in performing their contractual obligations if caused by uncontrollable and unforeseeable events such as natural disasters, pandemics, war, strikes, government actions, or other similar events making performance impossible or impractical.
- The affected party must notify the other as soon as reasonably possible after becoming aware of the event.
- Obligations impacted by the Force Majeure event are suspended during its continuance.
- If the Force Majeure event continues beyond a specified period, either party may terminate the Agreement with written notice.

This clause ensures fair allocation of risk and provides a mechanism for managing disruptions in the employment relationship caused by exceptional circumstances.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Force Majeure Clause):
- The agreement does not address or excuse performance failures or delays caused by uncontrollable external events.
- Both parties remain strictly liable for all contractual obligations regardless of unforeseen and extraordinary events.
- This could expose Employer and Employee to potential breach claims even during unavoidable disruptions.

Considerations:
- Including a Force Majeure clause is advisable to safeguard against risks from events beyond either party’s control.
- The description and scope of "Force Majeure Events" and the continuance period for termination should be tailored to the specific industry and legal environment.
- Local laws may impact how Force Majeure clauses are interpreted and enforced.

name: Force Majeure Event Continuance Duration
description:
This parameter specifies the predefined time period (duration) after which, if a Force Majeure Event continues without resolution, either party to the employment agreement may terminate the contract by providing written notice.

Function in the Clause: The Force Majeure clause typically suspends the obligations of both Employer and Employee while an uncontrollable event is ongoing. However, it is not indefinite. This parameter sets a clear, contractual maximum duration for how long the parties must tolerate the suspension before having an option to terminate.

Format and Units: This duration is usually expressed in a measurable time unit such as days, weeks, or months (e.g., "60 days", "3 months"). The exact unit and value are defined when configuring the employment agreement.

Effect of Reaching the Duration: If the Force Majeure Event persists beyond this duration, either the Employer or the Employee can give written notice to terminate the employment contract. This protects both parties from indefinite suspension and uncertainty regarding employment status during prolonged force majeure situations.

Balance Consideration: Setting a reasonable continuance period balances operational flexibility—allowing both parties time to recover or adapt—with the need for certainty and the ability to exit the relationship if the disruption is protracted.

Example Usage: If its set to "90 days," neither party would be liable for delays up to that period, but if the force majeure event lasts beyond 90 days, either party may terminate the agreement with written notice.

name: Governing Law and Dispute Resolution
description:
This parameter controls whether the employment agreement includes a clause that defines the governing law, the relationship with employer policies, and the dispute resolution process for any issues arising under the employment contract.

When set to TRUE (Include Clause):
- The agreement states that, except for provisions explicitly set forth in the contract, all employment terms and conditions are governed by the Employer’s policies and employee handbook, which may be updated from time to time with reasonable notice to the Employee. In addition, all applicable laws and regulations apply.
- It provides that, in the event of any conflict between the terms of the employment agreement and the Employer’s policies or applicable law, the provisions of the employment agreement generally prevail unless mandatory laws require otherwise.
- The agreement specifies that it is governed by and construed under the laws of a designated jurisdiction, with both parties agreeing to the exclusive jurisdiction of that jurisdiction’s courts to resolve disputes related to the agreement.
- It confirms that nothing in the agreement removes or limits any protections or benefits to which the Employee is entitled under mandatory legal provisions in the place where the Employee habitually works.

When set to FALSE (Exclude Clause):
- The employment agreement does not explicitly set out the governing law or dispute resolution terms.
- There may be less clarity on which laws govern the agreement or where related disputes must be resolved.
- The relationship between the Agreement and employer policies may be less clearly defined.

Considerations:
- Including such a clause is standard and advisable to ensure clarity on legal governance and dispute management.
- The chosen governing law jurisdiction should reflect the primary operational location or employer’s jurisdiction.
- The clause helps protect both Employer and Employee by clarifying applicable legal frameworks and preserving mandatory employee rights.

name: Mandatory Mediation Before Litigation
description:
parameter governs whether the Parties agree to attempt good faith mediation to resolve any disputes or claims arising out of or relating to the employment agreement.

If enabled (true), the Parties commit to resolving disputes through good faith mediation, which must conclude within a specified timeframe after one Party provides written notice to the other.

The mediation process serves as a structured, confidential, and non-binding attempt to reach a mutually agreeable resolution before resorting to formal dispute resolution methods such as arbitration or litigation.

If mediation fails or no agreement is reached within the prescribed deadline, the Parties will proceed to resolve the dispute according to the dispute resolution provisions set forth elsewhere in the agreement.

This parameter promotes early, collaborative problem-solving and helps minimize the cost, time, and adversarial nature of employment disputes.

When disabled (false), the agreement may omit mandatory mediation, allowing Parties to directly pursue other dispute resolution processes without mediation as a prerequisite.

name: Mediation Deadline Duration
description:
This parameter sets the maximum duration within which mediation must be concluded following a Party’s written notice of a dispute related to the employment agreement.

It establishes a clear timeframe to ensure mediation proceeds promptly and does not unduly delay final dispute resolution.

Timely completion of mediation encourages efficient, cooperative efforts to resolve conflicts before escalating to arbitration, litigation, or other formal methods.

The deadline balances allowing sufficient time for meaningful negotiation and the need to avoid prolonged uncertainty or operational disruption.

Parties agree in advance to engage in good faith mediation efforts within this prescribed period, fostering a structured dispute resolution process.

If mediation does not resolve the dispute within the deadline, the Parties proceed to the subsequent dispute resolution stage outlined in the agreement.

A 30-day default is widely accepted in employment dispute mediation clauses as providing a practical, balanced timeframe for effective mediation.

name: Change to the Employment Agreement
description:
This parameter determines how changes to the Employment Agreement or the Employee’s terms of employment can be made, specifying whether both parties must agree in writing or whether the Employer has the discretion to make reasonable changes unilaterally with notice.

Possible Values and Their Effects:
Value: both-parties
Requirement for Amendments: Any variation or amendment to the Agreement will only be effective if it is made in writing and signed by both the Employer and the Employee.
Implications:
Ensures that changes cannot be imposed unilaterally by either party.
Protects the Employee from unexpected or unwanted contractual changes.
Promotes mutual agreement and transparency for contract modifications.
Formalizes the process of amending the Agreement, reducing risk of disputes.
